16:26:00","modified":"2018-06-25 20:18:19","title":"Creedence Clearwater Revival","subtitle":null,"slug":"creedence-clearwater-revival-3-47884","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Stephen Malkamus<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p>My parents had basically nine vinyl albums, all greatest hits: the Beatles&apos; red\/blue albums, Carpenters, Neil Diamond, Elton John, the Beach Boys&apos; <em>Endless Summer<\/em>, Jim Croce, Gordon Lightfoot &#8230; and <em>Creedence Gold.<\/em> <em>Creedence<\/em> was the one I took. It has perhaps the Dullest Expensive Album Cover ever, with the foldout profiles of the band members, but it sat proudly next to Devo, Kiss, the Yardbirds, the Stones&apos; early albums (they were cheap), the <em>Decline of Western Civilization<\/em> soundtrack and the Dead Kennedys&apos; <em>Fresh Fruit for Rotting Vegetables.<\/em> I was pretty much just into &quot;Suzie Q&quot; and &quot;Born on the Bayou&quot; back then, but I came to appreciate almost everything they ever did.<\/p>\n<p>The songs are great. You have swamp-boogie numbers of varying length (&quot;Green River,&quot; &quot;Born on the Bayou&quot;), catchy energy bursts (&quot;Fortunate Son,&quot; &quot;Sinister Purpose&quot;), pop (&quot;Have You Ever Seen the Rain,&quot; et al.) and the soul numbers (&quot;Long As I Can See the Light&quot;). They are all arranged well, have catchy melodies and solid rock lyrics.<\/p>\n<p>John Fogerty has an inimitable voice. He puts it to the test over and over &#x2014; and wins. The rhythm section is rad. You try to play this stuff and you&apos;ll see they had chops. The rhythm guitar kicks, too. Fogerty plays what I would if I was 22, more talented and into the blues.<\/p>\n<p>The records have their own vibe &#x2014; performance-based, few overdubs, like if some Memphis\/Booker T.-type band moved West and got a youth-culture injection. The focus is on the songs and not the rock star BS that was taking over back then. But they weren&apos;t afraid to create a mood. When Cream came out, everybody started a power trio. But basically, &quot;Suzie Q&quot; has all the drama you would ever need. John Fogerty wrote more classic songs in a three-year stretch than anyone other than the Beatles.<\/p>\n<p>Thank you, <a href=\"\/artist\/creedence-clearwater-revival\">Creedence<\/a>, for being popular and timeless enough to be on CD jukeboxes. Keep on chooglin&apos;.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"CCR","image_credit":"","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":370926,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135864-090ffde08633d0ea920f1e4dc6e98c8de5fe23fb.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135864-090ffde08633d0ea920f1e4dc6e98c8de5fe23fb.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135864-090ffde08633d0ea920f1e4dc6e98c8de5fe23fb.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135864-090ffde08633d0ea920f1e4dc6e98c8de5fe23fb.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135864-090ffde08633d0ea920f1e4dc6e98c8de5fe23fb.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135864-090ffde08633d0ea920f1e4dc6e98c8de5fe23fb.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div 21:22:00","modified":"2018-06-25 15:33:23","title":"The Drifters","subtitle":null,"slug":"the-drifters-83221","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Jerry Leiber<\/span>  and Mike Stoller<\/em><\/p>\n<p>Over the years, the <a href=\"\/artist\/the-drifters\">Drifters<\/a> were a couple of different great groups and a whole bunch of wonderful guys. In a way, that upheaval may be part of the reason they recorded so many immortal songs over such a long period.<\/p>\n<p>We were both fans of the Drifters even before we started writing, and later producing, for them. There was a real tradition of great singers in the group: Clyde McPhatter, Johnny Moore, Ben E. King and Rudy Lewis. Yet for all their fantastic records, the Drifters had the least stable lineup of any of the great vocal groups. They were in essence a band of hired guns, overseen by their management. Let&apos;s just say this wasn&apos;t necessarily a situation where guys were getting rich off the royalties.<\/p>\n<p>Our first cut writing for the Drifters was &quot;Ruby Baby,&quot; which Nesuhi Ertegun produced and Johnny Moore sang lead on, in 1955. We loved what they did with the song. Their management changed the lineup in 1958, and that&apos;s when the great Ben E. King came into the picture. The Drifters records that we&apos;re most associated with, including &quot;There Goes My Baby,&quot; come from that era.<\/p>\n<p>Ben E. King was this younger singer just coming up, yet he had this mature style that was so unusual. He was always wonderful to work with, and we had a truly great run together. People have said that &quot;There Goes My Baby&quot; was a very influential record because it helped set the stage for the Wall of Sound and Motown. Who are we to argue? Thanks to a great arrangement by Stan Applebaum, the song showed us how rock &amp; roll and strings could really work together. When King left, we worked with him as a solo artist, and the Drifters kept on having hits too, first with Rudy Lewis as the new lead singer. Upon Lewis&apos; death, Moore returned to the group in time for &quot;Under the Boardwalk.&quot;<\/p>\n<p>We wrote songs for the Drifters, but we also put the call out to all the best songwriters in our world. Doc Pomus and Mort Shuman came with perfect songs like &quot;This Magic Moment&quot; and &quot;Save the Last Dance for Me.&quot; Gerry Goffin and Carole King wrote &quot;Up on the Roof.&quot; We also put the Drifters together with Burt Bacharach &#x2014; who met Dionne Warwick at our office for a Drifters session.<\/p>\n<p>Through it all, the Drifters always had this exquisite vocal blend. It was warm and round and full and dripping with chocolate. Since we were involved in the Drifters&apos; career, it&apos;s probably not our place to declare their music immortal. But you have to say, they did pretty well.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Olaf Hajek","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":451234,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135069-square.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135069-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135069-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135069-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135069-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135069-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div 21:21:00","modified":"2018-06-25 15:33:30","title":"Elvis Costello","subtitle":null,"slug":"elvis-costello-4-85334","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Liz Phair<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"\/artist\/elvis-costello\">Elvis Costello<\/a> writes novels in three minutes. He gets inside your head, and he doesn&apos;t let go. I&apos;d pay a great amount of money to audit a course taught by him. If you love Elvis Costello, it&apos;s because you love what he&apos;s thinking &#x2014; the depth and breadth of his notice is astounding. Sometimes I wonder if he watches people on the Strand in London and makes up entire histories for them. (&quot;This person didn&apos;t pass the bar and has thyroid problems.&quot; &quot;They&apos;re jogging because they just went through a breakup.&quot;)<\/p>\n<p>When I was a teenager, it was a career aim for many of my friends to have a song written about them by Elvis Costello. His songs about women and girls are devastating, like arrows to the heart. There are very few artists who can depict a woman&apos;s life, her thoughts and desires and her failings, like he can. Most rock songs about women are from the outside looking in: They say, &quot;Babe, you&apos;re so hot, come sleep with me.&quot; Elvis&apos; songs say, &quot;I see you, and I know what you&apos;re doing.&quot; He catches us at our tricks, and that&apos;s always thrilling.<\/p>\n<p>He&apos;s a poet with a punk&apos;s heart. There&apos;s a Jerry Lee Lewis flavor to the way he just gets in there and lets it rip: His rocking stuff has a lot of raw power, a real physicality. Even when it&apos;s just him and a piano onstage, it&apos;s powerful. When I first heard him, I was blown away that someone could just spit those words out without even hitting the right notes, with no holding back and no shame. Of course, the Attractions were really important to his music &#x2014; if you&apos;re going to cram a whole book into one song, it helps to have a steady groove.<\/p>\n<p>Nobody sounds like him. People imitate Stevie Wonder or whomever, but how many people can do Elvis Costello? Not bloody many. His melodies weave in and out and all over the place, and you can tell they just spring out of him. Finally, Elvis is the definition of a career artist &#x2014; he&apos;s always coming up with a different sound, always challenging himself. All of his music tells you: You could come along for the ride &#x2014; but I&apos;m not stopping.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Roberto Parada","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":451458,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135068-square.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135068-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135068-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135068-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135068-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135068-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div 21:20:00","modified":"2018-06-25 15:33:37","title":"The Four Tops","subtitle":null,"slug":"the-four-tops-85424","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Smokey Robinson<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p>The <a href=\"\/artist\/the-four-tops\">Four Tops<\/a> are a one-in-a-million singing group. They were the best in my neighborhood in Detroit when I was growing up. When I was 11 or so, my first group was an early version of what would become the Miracles. Back then the Four Tops were called the Four Aims. We all used to sing on the corners, at school functions and at house parties. Sometimes we&apos;d have talent competitions. But all the groups in the neighborhood knew that if the Four Aims were going to be there, you were going to be singing for second place at best.<\/p>\n<p>They were the first group from the neighborhood that sang modern harmony: They could sing like a gospel group but then do R&amp;B like no one else. I love singers whom you can identify the first second they open their mouth, and Levi Stubbs is one of those; he&apos;s one of the greatest of all time. He has that distinctive voice, and his range is staggering. The combination of Levi, Obie Benson, Duke Fakir and Lawrence Payton was truly awesome.<\/p>\n<p>When they came to Motown and teamed up with Holland-Dozier-Holland, there was no looking back. They performed some of the most dramatic records ever written: &quot;Standing in the Shadows of Love,&quot; &quot;Bernadette,&quot; &quot;Reach Out I&apos;ll Be There,&quot; &quot;I Can&apos;t Help Myself&quot; and &quot;Baby I Need Your Loving.&quot; Later, when Holland-Dozier-Holland left, I co-wrote &quot;Still Water (Love)&quot; with Frank Wilson for the Four Tops.<\/p>\n<p>They were always great singers and great guys. When the Four Tops first came to Motown, the Miracles and I were the mainstays of the label, and the Temptations had just gotten there. But all the guys were very, very close. You&apos;d come back to town from a 51-night tour, and the first thing you did was shower and head back to Hitsville. We&apos;d play cards and shoot pool together into the early hours.<\/p>\n<p>The Four Tops will always be one of the best groups ever. Their music is forever.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Gregory Machess","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":451625,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135067-square.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135067-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135067-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135067-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135067-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135067-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div class=\"admz \" id=\"adm-in-list-x-20\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"adma boomerang \" data-device=\"Desktop\" data-width=\"728\">\n\t\t\t\t\n<div style=\"min-width:50px;min-height:75px;\"\n\tclass=\"pmc-adm-boomerang-pub-div ad-text\"\n\tdata-priority=\"8\"\n>\n\t<div id=\"gpt-dsk-tab-list-inbodyX-uid21\"\n\t\tclass=\" adw-728 adh-90\" data-is-adhesion-ad=\"\">\n\t\t<script type=\"application\/javascript\">\n\t\t\tblogherads.adq.push(function () {\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\tblogherads\n\t\t\t\t\t.defineSlot( 'banner', )\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t.setSubAdUnitPath(\"music\\\/list\\\/inbodyX\")\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t.addSize([[728,90],[3,3]])\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t.setLazyLoadMultiplier(2)\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t;\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t});\n\t\t<\/script>\n\t<\/div>\n<\/div>\n\t\t\t<\/div>\n\t\t\t\t<\/div>\n","data":[{"divId":"gpt-dsk-tab-list-inbodyX-uid21","displayType":"banner","targeting":[{"key":"pos","value":"mid"},{"key":"pos","value":"in-listX"},{"key":"pos","value":"btf"},{"key":"pos","value":"inbodyX"}],"lazyLoad":"yes","lazyLoadMultiplier":2,"zone":"music\/list\/inbodyX","sizes":[[728,90],[3,3]]}]}},{"ID":85578,"position":22,"positionDisplay":78,"date":"2011-04-20 21:20:00","modified":"2018-06-25 15:33:49","title":"The Stooges","subtitle":null,"slug":"the-stooges-85578","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Thurston Moore<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p>For me, the <a href=\"\/artist\/the-stooges\">Stooges<\/a> were the perfect embodiment of what music should be &#x2014; of wanting it to be alive, riding the edge of control. Their music was total high-energy blues, with the contemporary freakout of Jimi Hendrix and the free-jazz spirit of John Coltrane. Iggy wanted the Stooges to be what he&apos;d seen in Chicago as a young guy &#x2014; these old bluesmen playing so hard that, as Iggy once said, the music drips off you.<\/p>\n<p>I was 14 when I first saw a picture of Iggy onstage: shirtless, with his body spray-painted silver. He was sweating &#x2014; it looked like glitter sweat &#x2014; and he had a chipped tooth. He looked young and on fire. Iggy&apos;s parents were intellectuals &#x2014; his father was an English teacher &#x2014; and that gave him an edge. He had focus. Iggy believed what he was doing was important &#x2014; this self-reliant, anti-establishment art form.<\/p>\n<p>The Stooges&apos; sound was so evocative yet so simple. Scott Asheton played drums as if he was in an electric-blues band. On <em>The Stooges<\/em> and <em>Fun House<\/em>, while his brother Ron, the guitarist, was playing these loud bar-chord progressions, Scott was making the band rev and swing. And when I played with Ron for the soundtrack of <em>Velvet Goldmine<\/em>, the first week was a crash course on how to play Stooges songs. We went through those first two albums, and there was that Asheton swing again, the way he rocked the chord grooves.<\/p>\n<p><em>Raw Power<\/em> was made by a different lineup, with James Williamson on guitar and Ron on bass. It&apos;s the ultimate fuck-off. This is a band getting very strung out, putting so much blood and soul into what it&apos;s doing, and for the most part looked upon as trash. There&apos;s a damaged quality to David Bowie&apos;s original mix that is way ahead of its time.<\/p>\n<p>Seeing the Stooges in reunion with Mike Watt from the Minutemen on bass was awesome. When they played their first gig, in 2003 at Coachella, the first thing Iggy did was start jumping in the air, flipping the bird to the crowd &#x2014; &quot;Fuck you, fuck you and fuck you.&quot; Then Iggy turned to the side of the stage, where the elite were standing &#x2014; Sonic Youth, Queens of the Stone Age, the Red Hot Chili Peppers and the other all-access rock stars &#x2014; and he gave us the jerk-off motion. It was great. After all this time, he&apos;s still at war.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Tim Bower","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":452041,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135066-square.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135066-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135066-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135066-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135066-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135066-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div 21:19:00","modified":"2018-06-25 15:33:43","title":"Beastie Boys","subtitle":null,"slug":"beastie-boys-4-85507","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Darryl &quot;DMC&quot;<\/span>  McDaniels<\/em><\/p>\n<p>In the early days of rap, the conventional wisdom was that only black people were supposed to like hip-hop and only white people were supposed to like rock. But it wasn&apos;t like that. In Run-DMC, we were rapping over rock beats. The Beasties were a punk band listening to hip-hop.<\/p>\n<p>I met the <a href=\"\/artist\/beastie-boys\">Beastie Boys<\/a> in Rick Rubin&apos;s dorm room at NYU. What bugged me out about the Beasties was that they knew everything about hip-hop &#x2014; the Cold Crush Brothers, the Treacherous Three and Afrika Bambaataa, all the old-school shit. In addition, they could rap, they could sing and they could play instruments.<\/p>\n<p>Run-DMC gave &quot;Slow and Low&quot; to the Beastie Boys. The song was basically their blueprint. But then they started writing anita kunztheir own rhymes, and when <em>Licensed to Ill<\/em> came out, it went to Number One. They were writing songs we wished we had written, like &quot;No Sleep Till Brooklyn.&quot; They put rock with rap like we did, but it made so much sense when they did it because they were punk rockers.<\/p>\n<p>The first time we toured with the Beastie Boys was the <em>Raising Hell<\/em> tour in 1986: Run-DMC, Whodini, LL Cool J and the Beastie Boys. We were playing the Deep South &#x2014; Crunkville, before there was crunk &#x2014; and it was just black people at those shows. The first night was somewhere in Georgia, and we were thinking, &quot;I hope people don&apos;t leave when they see them.&quot; But the crowd loved them, because they weren&apos;t trying to be black rappers. They rapped about shit they knew about: skateboarding, going to White Castle, angel dust and television. Real recognizes real.<\/p>\n<p>One of the most significant things about the Beasties is their longevity. They&apos;ve put out genius records for decades. When <em>Paul&apos;s Boutique<\/em> came out, it didn&apos;t sell as well as their debut. Now people realize it&apos;s one of the best albums of the Eighties.<\/p>\n<p>Each of the Beastie Boys has a different personality. Mike D is the examiner: He looks around, he takes in all the information, he&apos;s a little laid-back. MCA was always the mature one, but he could be a fool when it was time to be a fool. And Ad-Rock is just full of life. He&apos;s approachable, affectionate and funny. But maybe my favorite thing about the Beastie Boys is that they&apos;re worldly. They taught me and many other people a lot about life, people and music.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Anita Kunz","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":451842,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135065-square.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135065-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135065-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135065-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135065-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135065-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div 21:18:00","modified":"2018-06-25 15:33:56","title":"The Shirelles","subtitle":null,"slug":"the-shirelles-85687","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Paul Shaffer<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"\/artist\/the-shirelles\">The Shirelles<\/a> had a &quot;sound,&quot; a word that people from the Sixties vocal-group era use with a lot of reverence. Shirley Alston Reeves, who did most of the group&apos;s lead vocals, wasn&apos;t a gospel shouter like Arlene Smith of the Chantels. Shirley was more sentimental and street. When she said, &quot;Baby, it&apos;s you,&quot; you thought, &quot;Baby, it <em>is<\/em> me.&quot;<\/p>\n<p>They weren&apos;t the first girl group, but the Shirelles were the first to have many hits. They influenced everyone from the Ronettes and Motown girl groups like the Supremes to the Beatles, who covered &quot;Baby It&apos;s You&quot; and &quot;Boys.&quot; The Shirelles were given some of the all-time greatest songs to sing: &quot;Will You Love Me Tomorrow,&quot; &quot;Soldier Boy,&quot; &quot;Tonight&apos;s the Night,&quot; &quot;Mama Said.&quot; But what&apos;s interesting to me is that they wrote their very first hit, &quot;I Met Him on a Sunday,&quot; themselves, when they were still high school students in New Jersey. It was on this song that the group combined doo-wop with very accessible pop melodies: It began with the whole group singing, &quot;Doo ron, day ron, day ron day papa, doo ron,&quot; then one of them would sing, &quot;Well, I met him on a Sunday.&quot; It was the cutest thing.<\/p>\n<p>The girl-group sound was everything to me. As a kid, I used to sit at home after school and just bang out those songs on the piano. Later in life, in the early Nineties, I witnessed a wonderful moment, when the Shirelles were honored by the Rhythm &amp; Blues Foundation. The three living members of the group &#x2014; Shirley, Beverly Lee and Doris Jackson &#x2014; were at the awards ceremony. The fourth member, Addie &quot;Micki&quot; Harris, had died in 1982. I had heard that they hadn&apos;t seen each other in quite a while, so there was some apprehension when the three of them took the stage. They certainly hadn&apos;t planned to perform. But when Doris took her award in hand, she said, &quot;This is dedicated to the one I love,&quot; and then they just started singing it.<\/p>\n<p>They sounded fantastic. The band fell into place, and people in the audience just fell over. After that, Shirley, Beverly and Doris were having so much fun that they went into &quot;Soldier Boy.&quot; This was a group that hadn&apos;t sung together in years, but they sounded heavenly. I was so inspired, I stood at attention and saluted. There was nothing else I could do.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Gary Kelly","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":452219,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135064-square.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135064-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135064-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135064-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135064-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135064-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div 16:28:00","modified":"2018-06-25 15:34:01","title":"Eagles","subtitle":null,"slug":"eagles-85769","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Sheryl Crow<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"\/artist\/eagles\">The Eagles<\/a> forever changed country and rock, but I just think of what they did as being great American music. It&apos;s amazing how one band could take all those influences &#x2014; country and rock, of course, but also soul, R&amp;B and folk &#x2014; and still sound so distinctive.<\/p>\n<p>The Eagles were a real band. After an album or two, Don Henley and Glenn Frey turned into one of rock&apos;s all-time great songwriting teams. But everyone contributed material and incredible musicianship to the effort: Randy Meisner and Bernie Leadon, then Don Felder, and later Joe Walsh and Timothy B. Schmit. They started out in the age of the sensitive singer-songwriter, and their music was as smart and sensitive as anyone&apos;s, but when they called upon it, they also had the power of a great rock &amp; roll band.<\/p>\n<p>The first song of theirs that I vividly remember hearing was &quot;Take It Easy.&quot; Those lyrics &#x2014; by Frey and Jackson Browne &#x2014; could have been from any Merle Haggard or Willie Nelson song, but the instrumentation and energy were decidedly rock. The combination sounded so powerful.<\/p>\n<p>I also remember being on a long cross-country family road trip as a kid, driving across the Texas desert at night. The only radio station we could get was a scratchy AM station from who knows where. The haunting opening strains of &quot;Hotel California&quot; came on the radio. My father thought that all of us kids were asleep; I immediately assumed that he would shut the radio off. But he didn&apos;t. He couldn&apos;t resist it any more than I could.<\/p>\n<p>The Eagles provided the soundtrack to so many of my summers, and likely many of yours, too. Their melodies and harmonies have always been instantly familiar. &quot;Desperado,&quot; &quot;Take It to the Limit,&quot; &quot;Tequila Sunrise&quot; and &quot;Best of My Love&quot; are some of the best pop songs ever written. To this day, it simply doesn&apos;t get any better than that guitar riff from &quot;Life in the Fast Lane.&quot;<\/p>\n<p>When I sang backup for Don Henley in the early Nineties, it was a surreal experience, supplying vocals every night to Eagles songs. The audience&apos;s reaction to those classics cemented their value in my head. In my own way, I got to experience the power of the Eagles&apos; music. But then again, we all have.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Mark 21:17:00","modified":"2018-06-25 15:34:06","title":"Hank Williams","subtitle":null,"slug":"hank-williams-2-85998","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em>By Beck<\/em><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"\/artist\/hank-williams\">Hank Williams<\/a> songs like &quot;Lonesome Whistle&quot; and &quot;Your Cheatin&apos; Heart&quot; are wonderful to sing because there is no bullshit in them. The words, the melodies and the sentiment are all there, clear and true. It takes economy and simplicity to get to an idea or emotion in a song, and there&apos;s no better example of that than Hank Williams.<\/p>\n<p>Hank had a voice that split wood. From his records, it sounded like he was projecting from a completely different place in his body. It was a voice that could play roadhouses without amplification, that could cut through barroom crowds. The places he played were so tough that he hired a wrestler, Cannonball Nichols, to be his bass player. Hank lived what would have been a rock star&apos;s life &#x2014; full of touring, drinking and woman troubles.<\/p>\n<p>I bought a 10-song Hank Williams collection on vinyl for $4.99. It was like I unlocked a box: His music spoke to me. His records are enormously important to country music, but I think I responded to them because they sounded so exotic. It&apos;s significant that Hank learned to play guitar from an elderly black musician: Hank is the ultimate hillbilly, but there&apos;s other stuff going on. For a while he was my only reference point; I&apos;ve covered his songs for years. On <em>Sea Change<\/em>, I made a conscious effort to try to write songs as direct as Hank&apos;s.<\/p>\n<p>I see more and more people getting into his music today. When I played his songs early on, I used to get really sick of everyone in the crowd yelling &quot;yee-haw&quot; all the way through. But I&apos;ve noticed that there&apos;s been a rediscovery of the haunting quality of Hank Williams&apos; music. People are listening.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Marc Burckhardt","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":452545,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135062-square.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135062-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135062-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135062-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135062-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135062-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div 21:16:00","modified":"2018-06-25 19:28:43","title":"Radiohead","subtitle":null,"slug":"radiohead-9-86226","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Dave Matthews<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p>Every time I buy a <a href=\"\/artist\/radiohead\">Radiohead<\/a> album, I have a moment where I say to myself, &quot;Maybe this is the one that will suck.&quot; But it never does. I wonder if it&apos;s even possible for them to be bad on record.<\/p>\n<p>It belittles Radiohead to describe their music as having &quot;hooks.&quot; Their music talks to you, in a real way. It can take you down a quiet street before it drops a beautiful musical bomb on you. It can build to where you think the whole thing will crumble beneath its own weight &#x2014; and then Thom Yorke will sing some melody that just cuts your heart out of your chest. There&apos;s a point on the album <em>Kid A<\/em> where I start feeling claustrophobic, stuck in a barbed-wire jungle &#x2014; and then I suddenly fall out and I&apos;m sitting by a pool with birds singing. Radiohead can do all of these things in a moment, and it drives me fucking crazy.<\/p>\n<p>My reaction to Radiohead isn&apos;t as simple as jealousy. Jealousy just burns; Radiohead infuriate me. But if it were only that, I wouldn&apos;t go back and listen to those records again and again. Listening to Radiohead makes me feel like I&apos;m a Salieri to their Mozart. Yorke&apos;s lyrics make me want to give up. I could never in my wildest dreams find something as beautiful as they find for a single song &#x2014; let alone album after album. And every time, they raise their finger to the press and the critics and say, &quot;Nothing we do is for you!&quot; They followed their most critically acclaimed record, <em>OK Computer<\/em>, with their most radical change, <em>Kid A.<\/em> It&apos;s not that they&apos;re indifferent &#x2014; it&apos;s that the strength of character in their music is beyond their control.<\/p>\n<p>Seeing them perform makes me even angrier. No matter how much they let go in their shows, they never lose their clarity. There&apos;s no point where Jonny Greenwood or Ed O&apos;Brien will suddenly look up and say, &quot;Where the fuck are we?&quot; There are no train wrecks in Radiohead; every album and performance is wrenching. God, these guys have suffered, or they can fake it like nobody else.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Andrea 21:15:00","modified":"2018-06-25 19:28:47","title":"AC\/DC","subtitle":null,"slug":"ac-dc-5-86309","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Rick Rubin<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p>When I was in junior high, my classmates all liked Led Zeppelin. But I loved <a href=\"\/artist\/ac-dc\">AC\/DC<\/a>. I got turned on to them when I heard them play &quot;Problem Child&quot; on <em>The Midnight Special.<\/em> Like Zeppelin, they were rooted in American R&amp;B, but AC\/DC took it to a minimal extreme that had never been heard before. Of course, I didn&apos;t know that back then. I only knew that they sounded better than any other band.<\/p>\n<p>For AC\/DC, rock began with Chuck Berry and ended around Elvis. They poured their lifeblood into that groove, and they mastered it. <em>Highway to Hell<\/em> is probably the most natural-sounding rock record I&apos;ve ever heard. There&apos;s so little adornment. Nothing gets in the way of the push-and-pull between the guitarists Angus and Malcolm Young, bassist Cliff Williams and drummer Phil Rudd. For me, it&apos;s the embodiment of rock &amp; roll.<\/p>\n<p>When I&apos;m producing a rock band, I try to create albums that sound as powerful as <em>Highway to Hell.<\/em> Whether it&apos;s the Cult or the Red Hot Chili Peppers, I apply the same basic formula: Keep it sparse. Make the guitar parts more rhythmic. It sounds simple, but what AC\/DC did is almost impossible to duplicate. A great band like Metallica could play an AC\/DC song note for note, and they still wouldn&apos;t capture the tension and release that drive the music. There&apos;s nothing like it.<\/p>\n<p>The other thing that separates AC\/DC as a hard-rock band is that you can dance to their music. They didn&apos;t play funk, but everything they played was funky. And that beat could really get a crowd going. I first saw them play in 1979 at Madison Square Garden, before their singer Bon Scott died and was replaced by Brian Johnson. The crowd yanked all the chairs off the floor and piled them into a pyramid in front of the stage. It was a tribute to how great they were.<\/p>\n<p>I&apos;ll go on record as saying they&apos;re the greatest rock &amp; roll band of all time. They didn&apos;t write emotional lyrics. They didn&apos;t play emotional songs. The emotion is all in that groove. And that groove is timeless.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Christopher Kasch","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":452928,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135060-square.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135060-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135060-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135060-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135060-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135060-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div 21:14:00","modified":"2018-06-25 19:28:51","title":"Frank Zappa","subtitle":null,"slug":"frank-zappa-3-86388","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Trey Anastasio<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p>In the early years of Phish, people often said we were like &quot;<a href=\"\/artist\/frank-zappa\">Frank Zappa<\/a> meets the Grateful Dead&quot; &#x2014; which sounds very bizarre. But Zappa was incredibly vital to me, as a composer and guitarist. I think he was the best electric-guitar player, other than Jimi Hendrix. Zappa conceptualized the instrument in a completely different way, rhythmically and sonically. Every boundary that was possible on the guitar was examined by him.<\/p>\n<p>I&apos;ll never forget the first time I saw him live, in New York, when I was in high school. He would leave his guitar on a stand as he conducted the band. And he would not pick up the guitar until everything was totally together. There would be this moment &#x2014; this collective breath from the audience &#x2014; as he walked over, picked it up and started playing the most ripping, beautiful solo. When he played, he was in communion with the instrument.<\/p>\n<p>I also saw Zappa at Memorial Auditorium in Burlington, Vermont, on his last tour, in 1988. He did this guitar solo in &quot;City of Tiny Lites&quot; where everybody in the band dropped out except drummer Chad Wackerman. I was in the balcony near the side of the stage. When Zappa turned his back on the audience to play with Chad, I saw this huge smile on his face. But this was also the guy who did 87orchestral pieces like <em>The Yellow Shark.<\/em> It&apos;s hard to believe somebody could do so many different things.<\/p>\n<p>Zappa was a huge influence on how I wrote music for Phish. Songs like &quot;You Enjoy Myself&quot; and &quot;Split Open and Melt&quot; were completely charted out because he had shown me it was possible. And when I played at Bonnaroo with my 10-piece band, we did two covers, &quot;The Devil Went Down to Georgia&quot; and &quot;Sultans of Swing.&quot; In both songs, I had the horn section play the guitar solos, note for note. I never would have thought of doing that if I hadn&apos;t seen Zappa do &quot;Stairway to Heaven&quot; in Burlington with the horns playing Jimmy Page&apos;s entire guitar solo, in harmony.<\/p>\n<p>There is a whole generation of musicians coming up who can&apos;t play their instruments. Because of stuff like Pro Tools, they figure they can fix it all in the studio. With Frank, his musicians were pushed to the absolute brink. Phish tried hard to do that too: to take our four little instruments and do as much as we could with them. I would not have envisioned that without him.<\/p>\n<p>Zappa gave me the faith that anything in music was possible. He demystified the whole thing for my generation: &quot;Look, these are just instruments. Find out what the range is, and start writing.&quot;<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Owen Smith","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":453102,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135059-square.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135059-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135059-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135059-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135059-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135059-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div class=\"admz \" id=\"adm-in-list-x-28\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"adma boomerang \" data-device=\"Desktop\" data-width=\"728\">\n\t\t\t\t\n<div style=\"min-width:50px;min-height:75px;\"\n\tclass=\"pmc-adm-boomerang-pub-div ad-text\"\n\tdata-priority=\"8\"\n>\n\t<div id=\"gpt-dsk-tab-list-inbodyX-uid29\"\n\t\tclass=\" adw-728 adh-90\" data-is-adhesion-ad=\"\">\n\t\t<script type=\"application\/javascript\">\n\t\t\tblogherads.adq.push(function () {\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\tblogherads\n\t\t\t\t\t.defineSlot( 'banner', 'gpt-dsk-tab-list-inbodyX-uid29' )\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t.setTargeting( 'pos', [\"mid\",\"in-listX\",\"btf\",\"inbodyX\"] )\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t.setSubAdUnitPath(\"music\\\/list\\\/inbodyX\")\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t.addSize([[728,90],[3,3]])\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t.setLazyLoadMultiplier(2)\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t;\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t});\n\t\t<\/script>\n\t<\/div>\n<\/div>\n\t\t\t<\/div>\n\t\t\t\t<\/div>\n","data":[{"divId":"gpt-dsk-tab-list-inbodyX-uid29","displayType":"banner","targeting":[{"key":"pos","value":"mid"},{"key":"pos","value":"in-listX"},{"key":"pos","value":"btf"},{"key":"pos","value":"inbodyX"}],"lazyLoad":"yes","lazyLoadMultiplier":2,"zone":"music\/list\/inbodyX","sizes":[[728,90],[3,3]]}]}},{"ID":86552,"position":30,"positionDisplay":70,"date":"2011-04-20 21:13:00","modified":"2018-06-25 19:28:55","title":"The Police","subtitle":null,"slug":"the-police-86552","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Brandon Flowers<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p>Oscar Wilde said that an artist has succeeded if people don&apos;t understand his work but they still like it. By that standard, the <a href=\"\/artist\/the-police\">Police<\/a> were a huge success. Their songs are universal &#x2014; they&apos;re part of all of our lives. You hear them on both pop and classic-rock stations, and they&apos;ll be played on the radio in Germany 100 years from now. At the same time, everything they did was really smart and worked on a few levels; you could love a particular song, then realize a year later that you had totally missed the meaning.<\/p>\n<p>Take &quot;Every Breath You Take.&quot; It&apos;s a great trick &#x2014; it&apos;s impossibly catchy, people play it at their weddings, but it&apos;s a stalker song. &quot;Roxanne&quot; is blatantly about a hooker &#x2014; it&apos;s not about how Sting loves her and broke her heart, it&apos;s just about how she&apos;s a hooker. People don&apos;t realize how unique that is. All of us are lucky to have heard songs as good as &quot;Message in a Bottle,&quot; &quot;Walking on the Moon&quot; and &quot;King of Pain&quot; on the radio. Sting already had a career and a degree when the Police made it; he wasn&apos;t afraid of sounding like a grown-up.<\/p>\n<p>My favorite is &quot;Don&apos;t Stand So Close to Me,&quot; the one about the teacher and the young girl. That kind of storytelling has fallen out of pop music, for the most part. &quot;Don&apos;t Stand&quot; would be great to listen to no matter what the lyrics were &#x2014; it could have just been about some girl &#x2014; but the story makes it spooky and powerful. My favorite line is &quot;Wet bus stop\/She&apos;s waiting\/His car is warm and dry&quot; &#x2014; he communicates the entire song with those 11 words.<\/p>\n<p>Of course, the Police were amazing musicians. They were professionals who came up during the punk era and found their messages later on. I&apos;m a big fan of how they used reggae. Bands like the Clash had already mixed it with punk, but the Police did it flat-out &#x2014; it was like reggae for music geeks. Sting played bass and sang, which you don&apos;t see very often. He commanded both the rhythm section and melodies in the band. Stewart Copeland is a great drummer &#x2014; you have to be to give songs like &quot;Roxanne&quot; and &quot;So Lonely&quot; their drive and also throw that reggae in there. Andy Summers has both great technique and rhythmic sense. It&apos;s amazing how many rock bands with serious grooves are made up of skinny English dudes.<\/p>\n<p>The Police matured really quickly. All bands should pay attention to that. You should always try to keep moving forward.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Tim O'Brien","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":453280,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135058-square.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135058-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135058-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135058-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135058-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135058-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div 21:12:00","modified":"2018-06-25 19:29:03","title":"Jackie Wilson","subtitle":null,"slug":"jackie-wilson-86797","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Peter Wolf<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"\/artist\/jackie-wilson\">Jackie Wilson<\/a> was key in helping bridge the gap between an old-style R&amp;B and a new incarnation of soul. Even Elvis Presley knew why Wilson was called &quot;Mr. Excitement&quot;: I heard that seeing Wilson perform made the King want to hide under the table. The most spectacular Jackie Wilson show I ever saw was at Harlem&apos;s famed Apollo Theater, around 1960. When he took the stage, adorned in a magnificent white suit, he spread his arms open wide, as if trying to embrace the entire room. He started singing the opening notes of his song &quot;Doggin&apos; Around.&quot; The audience broke into screams. Even the way he casually held his hands while singing was hypnotic. His dancing was spellbinding &#x2014; twists and splits that left me in total disbelief. Quickly soaked in sweat (nobody knew how to sweat as good as Jackie Wilson), he took off his jacket and pretended he was going to throw it to the crowd, creating a pure sexual enchantment. There were real women in that audience who knew what they wanted. And what they wanted was Jackie Wilson.<\/p>\n<p>He seemed destined for such greatness, and yet his life ended up playing itself out like some cheap B-grade film noir. There was violence &#x2014; a crazed woman once shot him &#x2014; as well as tax problems, drugs, divorce and mob associations that made demands he couldn&apos;t refuse. While performing at the Latin Casino, in Cherry Hill, New Jersey, he had a massive coronary and hit his head hard as he fell. At the hospital, he lapsed into a coma. He remained in that state for eight years, as the people around him fought over his estate, before he died in 1984.<\/p>\n<p>I had the honor of inducting Jackie Wilson into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. As I waited backstage to present my speech, I was approached by three women arguing with one another as to who should be the one to go onstage and claim the award that was to be given to Jackie. Mr. Excitement would still not have peace.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Charles -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Rod Stewart<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p>I was on holiday with my parents in the late Sixties when I heard &quot;I Wish It Would Rain.&quot; I lived in England, where it fucking rains all the time, so it was appropriate. But that&apos;s also when I fell in love with David Ruffin&apos;s tenor &#x2014; it jumped out of the speakers and ravished my soul.<\/p>\n<p>Whether it was Ruffin or Dennis Edwards or Eddie Kendricks or Paul Williams singing lead, the <a href=\"\/artist\/the-temptations\">Tempts <\/a>were always an all-star vocal band. Throughout the Sixties and Seventies, the Tempts had an unprecedented string of hits: &quot;My Girl,&quot; &quot;The Way You Do the Things You Do,&quot; &quot;Ain&apos;t Too Proud to Beg,&quot; &quot;Just My Imagination.&quot; Later on, they broke ground with the psychedelic soul of &quot;Cloud Nine.&quot; I remember listening to the high-hat rhythms on that record over and over with the guys in the Jeff Beck Group. We&apos;d try to change every one of our songs to try and capture their drumbeats.<\/p>\n<p>When I got home from holiday, I immediately bought <em>Wish It Would Rain.<\/em> At that time I was very much into folk music and turning the corner into R&amp;B, and I&apos;ll never forget seeing that cover, with all the Tempts dressed as Foreign Legionnaires, sitting in the desert. Their outfits were wonderful &#x2014; I blame them for teaching me to wear loud colors. They also came up with the cutting-edge dance routines. Nobody moved like the Tempts.<\/p>\n<p>I&apos;d later become friends with David Ruffin &#x2014; when our bands would play in Detroit, Ruffin would come to every show and we&apos;d sing &quot;(I Know) I&apos;m Losing You,&quot; a Temptations cover off my album <em>Every Picture Tells a Story.<\/em> His voice was so powerful &#x2014; like a foghorn on the <em>Queen Mary.<\/em> He was so loud.<\/p>\n<p>My children grew up loving the Temptations, and we tried to see them every time they came to town. They would always pick me out of the audience with a spotlight, trying to get me up to the stage. But I never did. I&apos;m too frightened.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Anita 21:03:00","modified":"2018-06-25 19:29:11","title":"Cream","subtitle":null,"slug":"cream-2-86930","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Roger Waters<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p>I was in my third year of classes at a place in London called the Regent Street Polytechnic School of Architecture, which is where I met Nick Mason and Rick Wright. At the end of each term we would have a show, and this time we had <a href=\"\/artist\/cream\">Cream<\/a> &#x2014; in a small hall where I had once played <em>Happy Loman in Death of a Salesman<\/em>, which is beside the point.<\/p>\n<p>The curtain drew back and the three of them started playing &quot;Crossroads.&quot; I had never seen or heard anything like it before. I was simply staggered by the amount of equipment they had: by Ginger Baker&apos;s double bass drum, by Jack Bruce&apos;s two 4-by-12 Marshall amps and by all of Eric Clapton&apos;s gear. It was an astounding sight and an explosive sound.<\/p>\n<p>Two-thirds of the way through their set, one of them said, &quot;We&apos;d like to invite a friend of ours from America out onstage.&quot; It was Jimi Hendrix, and that was the first night he played in England. He came on and did all that now-famous stuff, like playing with his teeth. That ticket cost about a pound or so. It might have been the best purchase I ever made.<\/p>\n<p>After that, Pink Floyd started to go professional, and we would run into Cream on the road. They affected so many people. Jimmy Page must have looked at Cream and thought, &quot;Fuck me, I think I&apos;ll do that,&quot; and then put together Led Zeppelin. Along with the Beatles, they gave those of us entering the business at that time something to aspire to that wasn&apos;t pop but was still popular.<\/p>\n<p>I remember Ginger Baker was insane back then, and I&apos;m sure he still is. He hit the drums harder than anyone I&apos;ve ever seen, with the possible exception of Keith Moon. And Ginger hit them in a rhythmic style all his own that was extraordinary. Eric Clapton we don&apos;t have to talk about &#x2014; it&apos;s obvious how amazing he is. Then there&apos;s Jack Bruce &#x2014; probably the most musically gifted bass player who&apos;s ever been.<\/p>\n<p>Cream were very innovative within the context of all the music coming from the West Coast of the U.S. at that time, from bands like the Doors and Love. Apart from being a great blues band, Cream had a real good go at so many other styles, even if some of it sounds a little silly now. There are songs on all the Cream albums that amaze me still, like &quot;Crossroads,&quot; &quot;Sunshine of Your Love,&quot; &quot;White Room&quot; and &quot;I Feel Free.&quot; They were desperately trying to write material that was truly progressive and original. And they achieved that.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Mark Gagnon","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":453944,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135054-square.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135054-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135054-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135054-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135054-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135054-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div 21:02:00","modified":"2018-06-25 19:29:15","title":"Al Green","subtitle":null,"slug":"al-green-3-86990","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Justin Timberlake<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"\/artist\/al-green\">Al Green<\/a> has helped overpopulate the world. He&apos;s got some serious babymaking music. But what makes him such an inspiration is the raw passion, the sincerity and the joy he brings to his music. People are born to do certain things, and Al was born to make us smile. You hear his voice and it lights everything up. Every time one of his songs starts playing &#x2014; whether it&apos;s &quot;You Ought to Be With Me,&quot; &quot;I&apos;m Still in Love With You,&quot; &quot;Love and Happiness&quot; or, of course, &quot;Let&apos;s Stay Together&quot; &#x2014; when the stomp starts and the guitar comes in, you know you&apos;re in for something full of sweet love. His songs weren&apos;t as political as Marvin Gaye and Donny Hathaway. But if those guys were speaking to you, Al Green was speaking for you.<\/p>\n<p>Al Green&apos;s voice will always remind me of driving the back roads of Memphis with my parents, listening to cassette tapes. Hearing Al as a kid made me want to become a singer and showed me that it was OK to have a softer, more falsetto voice. I really related to that, because I never had a big, boisterous, <em>American Idol<\/em> showstopping voice. Al, he was a crooner. The way he would squeeze out a note can&apos;t be trained and can&apos;t be imitated.<\/p>\n<p>Behind him was this incredible band. On songs like &quot;Tired of Being Alone,&quot; the horns are tasteful and restrained but completely funky. I always loved the way the mistakes were kept in on his albums, like the way the band is almost out of sync at the beginning of &quot;Love and Happiness.&quot; Even his messes are beautiful.<\/p>\n<p>Eventually I found out this man I idolized lived five minutes from me in my hometown. Then, years later, I went to the White House (back when Clinton was in office), and Al was there performing. He sang Sam Cooke&apos;s &quot;A Change Is Gonna Come,&quot; and the audience wept. After I released my first solo album, I was doing a TV special in Memphis, and I called him and asked if he&apos;d grace us with his presence. We sang &quot;Let&apos;s Stay Together&quot; on that stage, and it was a milestone in my short, unimportant career. I learned something incredible: Everything always has to be about the show. But Al Green is the show, and when you watch him perform, you see something honest and soulful and amazing.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Braldt Bralds","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":454145,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135053-square.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135053-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135053-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135053-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135053-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135053-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div class=\"admz \" id=\"adm-in-list-x-33\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"adma boomerang \" data-device=\"Desktop\" data-width=\"728\">\n\t\t\t\t\n<div 21:02:00","modified":"2018-06-25 19:29:18","title":"The Kinks","subtitle":null,"slug":"the-kinks-21-87087","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Peter Buck<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p>I&apos;ve got pretty much every note the <a href=\"\/artist\/the-kinks\">Kinks<\/a> recorded on my iPod &#x2014; certainly everything through 1980. And it all sounds good. The Kinks are the only major band from the Sixties I can think of that didn&apos;t go psychedelic, didn&apos;t do any of that crap that all of the other big bands did at the time. When everyone was writing song cycles about Eastern mysticism, Ray Davies was writing about a two-up\/two-down flat in some English suburb. Ray wrote songs about the things that were important to him. He invented his world and gave it life. And in that world, people weren&apos;t wearing Nehru jackets, smoking pot and jamming for 24 hours a day. The Kinks created a different world &#x2014; and I&apos;m glad they did it.<\/p>\n<p>When I first heard <em>Village Green Preservation Society<\/em>, in 1971, I got this picture in my head of small-town English life: village greens, draft beer. But when R.E.M. went to England in 1985, I drove through Muswell Hill &#x2014; and it certainly wasn&apos;t romantic-looking. I had this picture of a gorgeous vista &#x2014; when it&apos;s really a kind of grimy area. I realized these songs were all acts of imagination, that Ray was commemorating an England that was slipping away. There is a great air of sadness in those songs.<\/p>\n<p>I am amazed at how great the Kinks&apos; records sounded &#x2014; even though, when you listen closely, there is very little going on in them. <em>Village Green<\/em> is the best example: Unlike a lot of records of its time, it&apos;s not stuffed with a ton of instruments. And yet the songs are perfectly realized, well arranged.<\/p>\n<p>Ray wrote &quot;You Really Got Me&quot; on piano. Then he gives it to his brother Dave, this teenage maniac, who turns it into a demented guitar part. I read that an interviewer once asked Dave if he thought the Kinks had gone heavy metal in the Eighties. He said, &quot;It wasn&apos;t called heavy metal when I invented it.&quot; When R.E.M. started out, Dave&apos;s solo on that song was the only solo I knew how to play. So whenever I had to do a solo, I would just play that.<\/p>\n<p>The Kinks slipped into rock history through the back door. All of those great albums that we talk about now, like <em>Face to Face, Something Else by the Kinks<\/em> and <em>Village Green<\/em> &#x2014; nobody bought those records in the Sixties. But those of us who love those records &#x2014; and a lot of us are musicians &#x2014; have loved them for decades.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Christopher Kasch","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":454449,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135052-square.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135052-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135052-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135052-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135052-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135052-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div 21:01:00","modified":"2018-06-25 19:29:23","title":"Phil Spector","subtitle":null,"slug":"phil-spector-3-87306","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Jerry Wexler<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p>There are three kinds of record producers. The first kind is the documentarian &#x2014; someone like Leonard Chess, who goes into a bar on the South Side of Chicago, sees Muddy Waters with a six-piece combo, then pulls him into the studio the next day and says, &quot;Play what you played last night.&quot; The second is the type who serves the artist; I would be so brash as to include myself in that category, along with John Hammond, Ahmet and Nesuhi Ertegun, and Bob Thiele &#x2014; music fans who try to develop great singers.<\/p>\n<p>Then there&apos;s the producer who does it all. <a href=\"\/artist\/phil-spector\">Phil Spector<\/a> could be the greatest of these. For Spector, the song and the recording were one thing, and they existed in his brain. When he went into the studio, it came out of him, like Minerva coming out of Jupiter&apos;s head. Every instrument had its role to play, and it was all prefigured. The singer was just one tile in this intaglio. Songs such as the Righteous Brothers&apos; &quot;You&apos;ve Lost That Lovin&apos; Feelin&apos;&quot; and Ike and Tina Turner&apos;s &quot;River Deep, Mountain High&quot; had wonderful singers, but they were tiles. Phil would get the track ready, then call upon the artist and say, &quot;OK, now sing.&quot; There were songwriter-producers before him, but no one did the whole thing like Phil.<\/p>\n<p>When I first met him, he was very young, sleeping on the couch at the Atlantic Records offices and using the switchboard after hours. He was brash, cocky and talented. I remember that if I would vouchsafe an opinion about something when we were together in the studio &#x2014; a snare drum on a bridge of a song, or whatever &#x2014; Phil would say, &quot;Oh, man, I came here from California to make hits.&quot; It meant, &quot;Shut the fuck up and get out of my face.&quot; But like Dizzy Dean used to say, &quot;If you can do it, it ain&apos;t bragging,&quot; and Phil can do it: play piano and guitar, compose and produce.<\/p>\n<p>His music is impeccable. Where it comes from, I don&apos;t know.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Rob -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Janet Jackson<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"\/artist\/tina-turner\">Tina Turner<\/a> has become more than just a musical superstar and sex symbol, though she is definitely both of those things. For me &#x2014; and I imagine for millions of others &#x2014; Tina now stands as an enduring symbol of survival and of grace. Her music is a healing thing.<\/p>\n<p>Remember that famous introduction to &quot;Proud Mary,&quot; when Tina talks about liking things &quot;nice and &#8230; rough&quot;? We all know that she faced some rough times in her life. But the reality is that life never threw her anything that she couldn&apos;t handle. One of Tina&apos;s big hits is called &quot;We Don&apos;t Need Another Hero.&quot; Yet Tina has become a heroic figure for many people because of her tremendous strength. Tina doesn&apos;t seem to have a beginning or an end. I felt her music was always there, and I feel like it always will be.<\/p>\n<p>The story of Tina&apos;s rise and fall with Ike Turner is well-known. You can see what it was like in the movie <em>What&apos;s Love Got to Do With It.<\/em> But I believe it&apos;s time to put the Ike story to rest. The truth is that when Tina came back in the Eighties, she became much bigger than she was the first time around. Tina&apos;s story is not one of victimhood but one of incredible triumph.<\/p>\n<p>In the beginning, Tina&apos;s music was based on hard times and harsh realities. Think about a song like &quot;Nutbush City Limits.&quot; That was her story. But over the years, her story changed, and her music reflected those changes beautifully. Tina has the ability to dream, get out, get over and get on with it. She&apos;s transformed herself into an international sensation &#x2014; an elegant powerhouse. But wherever she may be, whether it&apos;s in Spain, Asia or Egypt, she&apos;s never forgotten her humble beginnings. Tina Turner knows who she is, and to this day, she remains one of the true greats. In every sense, the woman has legs.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Jody 20:58:00","modified":"2018-06-25 19:29:30","title":"Joni Mitchell","subtitle":null,"slug":"joni-mitchell-4-87579","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em>By Jewel<\/em><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"\/artist\/joni-mitchell\">Joni Mitchell<\/a> is a bigger icon than she is a star. Bob Dylan and Keith Richards became so famous that they&apos;re stars and icons. Joni is still unknown to lots of people. The impact she had wasn&apos;t flashy. But she influenced people who became stars.<\/p>\n<p>I remember a friend in high school playing me &quot;A Case of You,&quot; from <em>Blue.<\/em> I could tell that Joni was a painter by the way she wrote lyrics. She describes smells and sounds and uses fewer words to transmit more feeling. Her melodies are about shapes. The singing lines are slow, steep plateaus. One of the things I learned from Joni: If you can tell the story and keep things moving, you don&apos;t need to return to the chorus on time.<\/p>\n<p>What she writes is closer to journalism: On <em>Blue<\/em>, you hear everything she experienced, the highs and the lows. It&apos;s such a lonely album &#x2014; not in the &quot;I don&apos;t have any friends&quot; sense but in the sense that you&apos;re a little bit removed, and always watching. It takes a lot of courage to be that honest, especially as a woman. When she did it, it was a fluffy time &#x2014; pretty girls singing about pretty things.<\/p>\n<p>Joni had an edginess that not many women expressed then. Joni Mitchell never made a big deal out of being a woman. She had such a strong sexuality, but she didn&apos;t feel the need to deny that part of her in order to be taken seriously. She also didn&apos;t play it up &#x2014; although many of her songs are about sex.<\/p>\n<p>I met her at a <em>Vanity Fair<\/em> photo shoot. Stevie Wonder introduced us. He took my hand &#x2014; I guess I led him to her &#x2014; and he said, &quot;Joni, I&apos;d like you to meet Jewel.&quot; I just shook her hand and tried to swallow. I didn&apos;t have anything to say to her. Her influence on me is so obvious. I hope she can hear it.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Gerard
