15:06:00","modified":"2018-06-25 20:18:07","title":"Metallica","subtitle":null,"slug":"metallica-10-47532","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em>By Flea&#xA0;<\/em><\/p>\n<p>In 1984, I was on tour with my band, somewhere in the middle of America. It was around 3:00 or 4:00 in the morning. We&apos;re all crammed into our van, with all our equipment. It was raining. We were tired, we&apos;d been on the road. And this music comes on the radio. I couldn&apos;t believe that it existed. My mind was being blown by this beautiful violence that was unlike anything I&apos;d ever heard before.<\/p>\n<p>It wasn&apos;t punk rock. It wasn&apos;t heavy metal. It was precise and explosive and heavy. It was aggressive and intense, and it had these really wild and bizarre rhythm changes. But it still held together as a bitchin&apos;-ass song. I was singin&apos; along with it by the end, though it certainly wasn&apos;t using any conventional pop-song pattern that I had ever heard. That song was &quot;Fight Fire With Fire.&quot; And it opened up my mind to the mighty force of nature that is <a href=\"\/artist\/metallica\">Metallica<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>When Metallica started in 1981, they didn&apos;t really take your typical path to success. I don&apos;t know if massive stardom and selling a zillion records were on their minds when they were getting the ball rolling. But if they were aiming at becoming one of the most successful rock bands of all time, they sure were going about it in a kooky way. Maybe they were thinking they were going to break into Casey Kasem&apos;s Top 40 countdown with their debut record, <em>Kill &apos;Em All.<\/em> They were definitely going for a hit single with the song &quot;(Anesthesia) Pulling Teeth.&quot; A five-minute-long bass solo is a sure ticket to commercial success.<\/p>\n<p>That song is one of the great moments in rock history for the electric bass guitar. Every Cliff Burton-based solo I&apos;ve ever heard is a soulful, psychedelic, headbanging expression that rocks your world, trips your brain out and gets the house rockin&apos;. It&apos;s a beautiful piece of music played by an awesome rocker of a young man who was a masterpiece of a human being. I can never listen to any Metallica record without thinking of him. It is clear that the gift he gave lives on in that band&apos;s music.<\/p>\n<p>The fact that Metallica connected with the world in the way that they have is phenomenal. They have become a household name with music that is anything but mainstream. It&apos;s outsider music. And for it to do what it has done is truly mind-blowing. When I hear Metallica, I get this feeling that they&apos;re doing something that they have to do.<\/p>\n<p>There is this thing in them wound up so tight that they have to let it out, let that thing uncoil; it has to be released. An infinite well of sadness, a hell of a lot of pain and anger, but mostly, a lot of love for the process of releasing this stuff. For the people who give it up and get rocked by Metallica, the world is a less lonely place. When a person gets rocking to their music, everything else disappears, and that person is just one with the rock. It is an inexplicable, awesome thing, and I bow down to it. Pain and hurt can be a muse for great art. It&apos;s one of the greatest rites of passage for any artist, and it&apos;s something that touches us most deeply. Anyone who has ever been to a Metallica show, and banged their head, and thrown up the devil horns, has been a part of something great. Rocking so hard to the brutal beat of Metallica for those couple of hours, in a way, is as healthy as any spiritual exercise &#x2014; group meditation, any love-in, anything.<\/p>\n<p>Metallica&apos;s career is a huge, dynamic thing, and they have done it all. They have worked their way up from nothing, and written the jams that rocked the world. Metallica are fucking rad! The music is bitchin&apos;! It is unbelievable! And they continue to rock on. Whatever gets thrown at them, they persevere and they get stronger; they are a family. And they are as intense and inventive as ever.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Nathan Fox","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":370766,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135865-099550a380215cc19684cddb9e872851d116be64.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135865-099550a380215cc19684cddb9e872851d116be64.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135865-099550a380215cc19684cddb9e872851d116be64.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135865-099550a380215cc19684cddb9e872851d116be64.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135865-099550a380215cc19684cddb9e872851d116be64.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135865-099550a380215cc19684cddb9e872851d116be64.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div 20:57:00","modified":"2018-06-25 19:29:33","title":"The Sex Pistols","subtitle":null,"slug":"the-sex-pistols-87634","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Billie Joe<\/span>  Armstrong&#xA0;<\/em><\/p>\n<p>The <a href=\"\/artist\/the-sex-pistols\">Sex Pistols<\/a> released just one album &#x2014; <em>Never Mind the Bollocks, Here&apos;s the Sex Pistols<\/em> &#x2014; but it punched a huge hole in everything that was bullshit about rock music, and everything that was going wrong with the world, too. No one else has had that kind of impact with one album. You can hear their influence everywhere from Joy Division to Guns n&apos; Roses to Public Enemy to the Smiths to Slayer. <em>Never Mind the Bollocks<\/em> is the root of everything that goes on at modern-rock radio. It&apos;s just an amazing thing that no one&apos;s been able to live up to.<\/p>\n<p>It&apos;s a myth that these guys couldn&apos;t play their instruments. Steve Jones is one of the best guitarists of all time, as far as I&apos;m concerned &#x2014; he taught me how a Gibson should sound. Paul Cook was an amazing drummer with a distinct sound, right up there with Keith Moon or Charlie Watts. There are bands out there still trying to sound like the Sex Pistols and can&apos;t, because they were great players.<\/p>\n<p>The difference between John Lydon and a lot of other punk singers is that they can only emulate what he was doing naturally. There was nothing about him that was contrived. As far as the bass player goes, I don&apos;t think it was necessarily a mistake to replace Glen Matlock with Sid Vicious. Matlock was cool, but Sid was everything that&apos;s cool about punk rock: a skinny rocker who had a ton of attitude, sort of an Elvis, James Dean kind of guy. That said, there&apos;s nothing romantic about being addicted to heroin. He was capable of playing his instrument, but he was too fucked up to do it.<\/p>\n<p>The things that Lydon wrote about back in &apos;76 and &apos;77 are totally relevant to what&apos;s going on right now. They paint an ugly picture. No one ever had the guts to say what they said. The only person who did anything similar to it was Bob Dylan, and even Bob Dylan was never that blunt.<\/p>\n<p>When I first heard them, I was 14 or 15 and into a lot of heavy-metal and hard-rock music. I think I was at a girl&apos;s house. I remember hearing those boot stomps to &quot;Holidays in the Sun.&quot; And then the guitar came roaring through like thunder. By the time Lydon&apos;s vocal came in, I definitely wanted to destroy my past and create something new for myself. That&apos;s sort of the impact that they always had on me and my music. When I&apos;m trying to create something, I always refer to the Sex Pistols, because they show you what the possibilities are in music. You don&apos;t have to emulate them, but thanks to them, you can take it anywhere.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Roberto Parada","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":456263,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135048-square.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135048-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135048-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135048-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135048-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135048-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div 20:56:00","modified":"2018-06-25 19:29:38","title":"Aerosmith","subtitle":null,"slug":"aerosmith-15-87742","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em>By Slash&#xA0;<\/em><\/p>\n<p>I don&apos;t think this generation has a clue what classic <a href=\"\/artist\/aerosmith\">Aerosmith<\/a> was all about. But they were the template for what I do, as well as plenty of bands that came after Guns n&apos; Roses: Soundgarden, Nirvana, Alice in Chains and Pearl Jam all owed a serious debt to old-school Aerosmith.<\/p>\n<p>My big awakening happened when I was 14 years old. I&apos;d been trying to get into this older girl&apos;s pants for a while, and she finally let me come over to her house. We hung out, smoked some pot and listened to Aerosmith&apos;s <em>Rocks.<\/em> It hit me like a fucking ton of bricks. I sat there listening to it over and over, and totally blew off this girl. I remember riding my bike back to my grandma&apos;s house knowing that my life had changed forever. Now I identified with something.<\/p>\n<p>The key to <em>Rocks<\/em> is the first two songs &#x2014; &quot;Back in the Saddle&quot; and &quot;Last Child.&quot; That combination just ripped my head off. But my favorite song on the record has always been &quot;Nobody&apos;s Fault,&quot; which is the second song on the B side. Aerosmith had an aggressive, psychotic, drugged-out vibe, but at the same time they had a Stones-y blues thing going on. There was just nothing cooler than Aerosmith coming out of America at that point. What else was there? Foghat?<\/p>\n<p>When I was just starting to learn how to play guitar, Aerosmith gave me the shove I needed. I identified with Joe Perry&apos;s image, both soundwise and visually. He was streamlined in a way that reminded me of Keith Richards, was always wasted and had a careless guitar style that was really cool. But I was also totally into Brad Whitford&apos;s guitar solos, and he had a more direct influence on the way I play than anybody realizes. And anyone who sings needs to be exposed to Steven Tyler.<\/p>\n<p>My first Aerosmith concert was in 1978, at a festival with Van Halen &#x2014; they were incredibly loud and I barely recognized a note, but it was still the most bitchin&apos; thing I&apos;d ever seen. Soon after that, they broke up, which to me marked the end of Seventies rock. The next time I saw them was when they got back together six years later, and they were amazing. When Aerosmith are in the groove, they&apos;re just rock-solid. Not too long after that, Guns n&apos; Roses were asked to open for Aerosmith on their <em>Permanent Vacation<\/em> tour. We went to their manager&apos;s hotel room, and while he was in the bathroom we ordered $1,500 worth of room service and trashed the place. But they must have liked us a lot, because they put us on the bill anyway, and I&apos;ve known them ever since.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Josie Jammet","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":456520,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135047-square.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135047-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135047-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135047-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135047-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135047-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div class=\"admz \" id=\"adm-in-list-x-40\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"adma boomerang \" data-device=\"Desktop\" data-width=\"728\">\n\t\t\t\t\n<div style=\"min-width:50px;min-height:75px;\"\n\tclass=\"pmc-adm-boomerang-pub-div ad-text\"\n\tdata-priority=\"8\"\n>\n\t<div id=\"gpt-dsk-tab-list-inbodyX-uid41\"\n\t\tclass=\" adw-728 adh-90\" 20:55:00","modified":"2018-06-25 19:29:44","title":"Parliament and Funkadelic","subtitle":null,"slug":"parliament-and-funkadelic-87926","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Ice Cube&#xA0;<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p>When I was going out in the Eighties, you could get your ass kicked if you put on <a href=\"\/artist\/parliament-funkadelic\">Funkadelic<\/a>&apos;s &quot;(Not Just) Knee Deep&quot; at a house party. Some DJs wouldn&apos;t play that song or &quot;Flash Light,&quot; because a fight would start: The crazy motherfuckers at parties would become <em>real<\/em> crazy. &quot;Knee Deep&quot; was their coming-out music. At 15 minutes, it was so long and so good, it made you feel like now was the time. For whatever. George Clinton showed me that anything goes: You do what you feel.<\/p>\n<p>Obviously, he had great musicians on those albums: Bootsy Collins on the bass; Bernie Worrell, the best keyboard player I&apos;ve ever heard. Clinton would pull in people like James Brown&apos;s saxophone player Maceo Parker and anyone else he could find. The arrangements are always so unpredictable: high-pitched synthesizer sounds you never heard before, followed by straight-up beautiful music. He could turn the corniest things into funk.<\/p>\n<p>My uncle Jerry was a DJ and introduced me to all the P-Funk records when I was a little kid: <em>The Clones of Dr. Funkenstein, Mothership Connection.<\/em> I loved them because they reminded me of cartoons, but they were crazy and psychedelic, and the superheroes were black men. To this day they still have the best album covers I&apos;ve ever seen; they would sustain you as much as a video would today. I remember just sitting and staring at the cover of <em>Motor Booty Affair<\/em>; there was that picture of Sir Nose D&apos;Voidoffunk with a big-ass bird breathing down his neck. My favorite characters were Star Child and Sir Nose, even though Sir Nose was a sucker who didn&apos;t swim and didn&apos;t like the funk. I was too young to go to the concerts, but I&apos;d hear about them from my older brothers and sisters &#x2014; about the huge stage shows, and one story about a fan who stripped off all his clothes and ran the length of the arena. That bugged me out.<\/p>\n<p>In the end, nobody described George Clinton&apos;s music better than the man himself: It is &quot;Cosmic Slop,&quot; it is funkadelic &#x2014; funky and psychedelic. You feel a mothership connection. Clinton was a great marketer, in the best sense possible: He delivered what he promised. He was no Geraldo Rivera &#x2014; he was Muhammad Ali or LeBron James. His music never went away on the West Coast, and you can still hear his mark all over music today. Parliament and Funkadelic were 30 years ahead of their time.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Olaf Hajek","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":456777,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135046-square.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135046-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135046-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135046-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135046-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135046-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div class=\"admz \" id=\"adm-in-list-x-41\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"adma boomerang \" data-device=\"Desktop\" data-width=\"728\">\n\t\t\t\t\n<div style=\"min-width:50px;min-height:75px;\"\n\tclass=\"pmc-adm-boomerang-pub-div ad-text\"\n\tdata-priority=\"8\"\n>\n\t<div id=\"gpt-dsk-tab-list-inbodyX-uid42\"\n\t\tclass=\" adw-728 adh-90\" data-is-adhesion-ad=\"\">\n\t\t<script type=\"application\/javascript\">\n\t\t\tblogherads.adq.push(function () {\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\tblogherads\n\t\t\t\t\t.defineSlot( 'banner', )\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t.setSubAdUnitPath(\"music\\\/list\\\/inbodyX\")\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t.addSize([[728,90],[3,3]])\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t.setLazyLoadMultiplier(2)\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t;\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t});\n\t\t<\/script>\n\t<\/div>\n<\/div>\n\t\t\t<\/div>\n\t\t\t\t<\/div>\n","data":[{"divId":"gpt-dsk-tab-list-inbodyX-uid42","displayType":"banner","targeting":[{"key":"pos","value":"mid"},{"key":"pos","value":"in-listX"},{"key":"pos","value":"btf"},{"key":"pos","value":"inbodyX"}],"lazyLoad":"yes","lazyLoadMultiplier":2,"zone":"music\/list\/inbodyX","sizes":[[728,90],[3,3]]}]}},{"ID":88026,"position":43,"positionDisplay":57,"date":"2011-04-20 20:55:00","modified":"2018-06-25 19:29:50","title":"Grateful Dead","subtitle":null,"slug":"grateful-dead-5-88026","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Warren Haynes&#xA0;<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p>I didn&apos;t grow up a Deadhead. I didn&apos;t become a big fan until 1989. I first saw the band in 1979 &#x2014; I was 19 &#x2014; but my head was somewhere else at the time. My wife, Stefani, was a Deadhead, though, and after we met, in 1989, we&apos;d go to see them every chance we&apos;d get. One night, at Madison Square Garden, Bruce Hornsby &#x2014; who was playing keyboards with them &#x2014; pulled us up onstage and sat us behind his piano. We were 10 feet from Jerry Garcia, and you could see how that audience zeroed in on him. He was the focus of everything. There was a synchronicity between the <a href=\"\/artist\/the-grateful-dead\">Dead<\/a> and the crowd, and it was mesmerizing to watch Jerry, in his own understated way, steering that ship &#x2014; knowing it was a big ship that could barely be steered, but if anybody could steer it, it was him.<\/p>\n<p>Obviously, most of today&apos;s jam bands are influenced by the Dead. But what disappoints me about a lot of current music is that you don&apos;t hear any history in it.<\/p>\n<p>The Dead were aficionados of folk, acoustic blues and bluegrass &#x2014; particularly Garcia. In the songs he wrote with Robert Hunter, and in Bob Weir&apos;s stuff too, you&apos;re also hearing music from 40 years ago. Everyone focuses on the magic of Jerry&apos;s guitar playing and the vulnerability of his voice, but his sense of melody and chord changes was unbelievable. The ballads especially connected with me: &quot;Loser,&quot; &quot;Wharf Rat,&quot; &quot;Stella Blue.&quot; My song &quot;Lay of the Sunflower,&quot; on the Gov&apos;t Mule album <em>The Deep End<\/em>, has a lot of Garcia&apos;s melodic sensibilities.<\/p>\n<p>Before I joined the Dead in 2004, I played with Phil Lesh for about five years. He is one of the most original bass players ever. His background was in classical music; he looks at the bass guitar as a piece of the orchestra, like a low-pitch brass instrument. His job isn&apos;t just holding down the root notes &#x2014; he and the drummers, Mickey Hart and Bill Kreutzmann, are moving all over the place. A lot of the magic in the Dead&apos;s music came from Phil and Jerry learning how to play together, combining Phil&apos;s approach with Jerry&apos;s unique blend of influences.<\/p>\n<p>Jerry is still one of the few guitarists where as soon as you hear him, you know instantly who it is. As a guitar player, that is the thing I strive for: the distinct, recognizable personality that comes out in every note. There was a humanity in Jerry&apos;s guitar work as well as his singing that drew you in. He was a very personal guitarist; he played with more heart and soul than technique. And to me, that&apos;s what the best music is made of.<\/p>\n<p>As a band, the Dead also redefined success. They created this following that grew and grew, and they did it without compromising themselves. They survived in a world where survival didn&apos;t seem possible. They bucked the system and encouraged their fans to do the same: to be free thinkers. There are a lot of Deadheads who were completely different people before they connected with the Grateful Dead.<\/p>\n<p>The Dead still believe in that message. When I&apos;m with the Allman Brothers, the band always leaves it up to me how much of Duane&apos;s influence I should show. The Dead are like that too. They&apos;re never going to tell me, &quot;Play it more like Jerry&quot; or &quot;less like Jerry.&quot; It&apos;s always, &quot;Do what you think is right.&quot;<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Dale Stephanos","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":456973,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135045-square.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135045-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135045-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135045-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135045-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135045-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div 20:53:00","modified":"2018-06-25 19:29:56","title":"Dr. Dre","subtitle":null,"slug":"dr-dre-6-88124","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Kanye West&#xA0;<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p>Do hip-hop producers hold <a href=\"\/artist\/dr-dre\">Dr. Dre<\/a> in high esteem? It&apos;s like asking a Christian if he believes Christ died for his sins. Dre has a whole coast on his back. He discovered Snoop &#x2014; one of the two greatest living rappers, along with Jay-Z &#x2014; and signed Eminem, 50 Cent and the Game. He takes artists with great potential and makes them even better. I wonder where I&apos;d be right now if Dre had discovered me.<\/p>\n<p>I remember hearing Dre&apos;s music before I really knew who he was. I had a tape of Eazy-E&apos;s <em>Eazy-Duz-It<\/em> when I was 11 years old (until my mother found out it had curses on it and confiscated it). I didn&apos;t know what &quot;production&quot; was back then, but I knew I loved the music. The more I learned about producing hip-hop, the more I respected what Dre was doing. Think about how on old N.W.A records the beat would change four or five times in a single song. A million people can program beats, but can they put together an entire album like it&apos;s a movie?<\/p>\n<p>When I was learning to produce, working in a home studio in my mother&apos;s crib, I tried to make beats that sounded exactly like Timbaland&apos;s, DJ Premier&apos;s, Pete Rock&apos;s and, especially, Dr. Dre&apos;s. Dre productions like Tupac&apos;s &quot;California Love&quot; were just so far beyond what I was doing that I couldn&apos;t even comprehend what was going on. I had no idea how to get to that point, how to layer all those instruments. <em>The Chronic<\/em> is still the hip-hop equivalent of Stevie Wonder&apos;s <em>Songs in the Key of Life<\/em>. It&apos;s the benchmark you measure your album against if you&apos;re serious. But it&apos;s &quot;Xxplosive,&quot; off <em>2001<\/em>, that I got my entire sound from &#x2014; if you listen to the track, it&apos;s got a soul beat, but it&apos;s done with those heavy Dre drums. Listen to &quot;This Can&apos;t Be Life,&quot; a track I did for Jay-Z&apos;s <em>Dynasty<\/em> album, and then listen to &quot;Xxplosive.&quot; It&apos;s a direct bite.<\/p>\n<p>I first met Dre in December of 2003. He asked me to produce a track for the Game. At first I was star-struck, but within 30 minutes I was begging him to mix my next album. He&apos;s the definition of a true talent: Dre feels like God placed him here to make music, and no matter what forces are aligned against him, he always ends up on the mountaintop.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Sterling Hundley","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":457187,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135044-square.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135044-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135044-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135044-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135044-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135044-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div 20:52:00","modified":"2018-06-25 19:30:02","title":"Eric Clapton","subtitle":null,"slug":"eric-clapton-5-88208","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Steven Van<\/span>  Zandt<\/em>&#xA0;<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"\/artist\/eric-clapton\">Eric Clapton<\/a> is the most important and influential guitar player that has ever lived, is still living or ever will live. Do yourself a favor, and don&apos;t debate me on this. Before Clapton, rock guitar was the Chuck Berry method, modernized by Keith Richards, and the rockabilly sound &#x2014; Scotty Moore, Carl Perkins, Cliff Gallup &#x2014; popularized by George Harrison. Clapton absorbed that, then introduced the essence of black electric blues: the power and vocabulary of Buddy Guy, Hubert Sumlin and the three Kings &#x2014; B.B., Albert and Freddie &#x2014; to create an attack that defined the fundamentals of rock &amp; roll lead guitar.<\/p>\n<p>Maybe most important of all, he turned the amp up &#x2014; to 11. That alone blew everybody&apos;s mind in the mid-Sixties. In the studio, he moved the mic across the room from the amp, which added ambience; everybody else was still close-miking. Then he cranked the fucking thing. Sustain happened; feedback happened. The guitar player suddenly became the most important guy in the band.<\/p>\n<p>Intellectually, Clapton was a purist, although there was little evidence of it in the beginning. He supercharged every riff he knew, even things I remember as note-for-note tributes, like Freddie King&apos;s &quot;Hide Away,&quot; on John Mayall&apos;s <em>Bluesbreakers With Eric Clapton<\/em>. When he soloed, he wrote wonderful symphonies from classic blues licks in that fantastic tone, with all of the resonance that comes from distortion. You could sing his solos like songs in themselves.<\/p>\n<p>I first saw Clapton with Cream, at the Cafe Au Go Go in New York in 1967 &#x2014; sort of. I stood outside. It was sold out. I couldn&apos;t get in. But you could see them &#x2014; the band was right in the window. And it was loud, even outside. In those days, musically, Clapton was a total wild man. He stood there, not moving a muscle, while he issued the most savage assault you had ever experienced, unless you were at the debut of Tchaikovsky&apos;s &quot;1812 Overture&quot; and your seat was in front of the cannon. And when his creativity, passion, frustration and anger all came together, it was frightening. His solo in &quot;Crossroads&quot; on <em>Wheels of Fire<\/em> is impossible: I don&apos;t know how he kept time while he played.<\/p>\n<p>I&apos;ve never said more than a casual hello to Eric, so none of this is inside information. But I believe that his guitar playing changed radically in the early Seventies because singing and songwriting became more important to him, and Robert Johnson had a lot to do with that. Clapton was so moved by Johnson&apos;s music that he wanted to write and sing with the same passion, clarity and truth. You hear the frustration &#x2014; of not being able to do that &#x2014; in his Sixties guitar work. The first time I heard real anger and aggressive sexuality expressed in guitar playing was on that Mayall record. If the solo in &quot;Have You Heard&quot; isn&apos;t the sound of a cock ripping through trousers on its way to the promised land, I don&apos;t know what is.<\/p>\n<p>Bob Dylan&apos;s <em>Basement Tapes<\/em> and the Band&apos;s <em>Music From Big Pink<\/em> started a move back to American traditional music, and those recordings were a big influence on Clapton. Around the same time, Delaney and Bonnie Bramlett were encouraging him to write and sing. You can hear how good he is at both on <em>Eric Clapton<\/em>, the album he made with them, as well as his change in tone from Gibson-dirty to Stratocaster-clean.<\/p>\n<p><em>Layla<\/em> was, for me, the last time everything &#x2014; the singing, songwriting and guitar playing &#x2014; were all at the same high intensity level. It&apos;s Clapton&apos;s most original interpretation of the blues, because the hellhounds on his trail had a face: unrequited love. But Clapton&apos;s guitar playing is still terrific. The thing is, he had seven years of the most extraordinary, historic guitar playing ever &#x2014; and 40 years of doing good work. Being the best has got to wear you out. So he pulled back, like Dylan and Lennon did. The sprint is cool &#x2014; the marathon is better. Clapton has followed in the footsteps of his mentors: He&apos;s become a journeyman.<\/p>\n<p>Anyone who plays lead guitar owes him a debt of gratitude. He wrote the fundamental language, the binary code, that everyone uses to this day.<\/p>\n<p>The day may come, if you&apos;re a young rocker, when you&apos;ll hear one of Clapton&apos;s mellow, contemporary ballads on the radio and think, &quot;What&apos;s the big deal?&quot; Put on &quot;Steppin&apos; Out.&quot; And bow down.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Dan Brown","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":457385,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135043-square.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135043-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135043-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135043-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135043-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135043-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div 20:41:00","modified":"2018-06-25 19:30:16","title":"Howlin&#8217; Wolf","subtitle":null,"slug":"howlin-wolf-88369","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Buddy Guy&#xA0;<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p>That man was the natural stuff. When I first heard <a href=\"\/artist\/howlin-wolf\">Howlin&apos; Wolf<\/a>&apos;s records, I thought that deep, scratchy voice was a fake voice, just the way he sang &#x2014; until I met him. He said, &quot;Hello,&quot; and I thought, &quot;Uh-oh, this isn&apos;t fake. This is for real.&quot; Wolf&apos;s conversation was the same as his singing. Matter of fact, the first time I met him, I started tapping my feet as he was talking.<\/p>\n<p>His first big records, like &quot;Moanin&apos; at Midnight&quot; and &quot;How Many More Years&quot; &#x2014; I&apos;d hear them on the radio when I was still in Louisiana, on WLAC out of Nashville. We had an old battery-powered radio, and we&apos;d listen to this half-hour program that came on at night. I&apos;d hear the man&apos;s voice and try to picture what he looked like. I thought he was a big, light-skinned guy. Then I went up to Chicago &#x2014; September 25th, 1957. The next year, I was meeting all of the great blues musicians: Muddy Waters, Sonny Boy Williamson, Howlin&apos; Wolf. And when I saw Wolf, yes, he was a big guy. But he wasn&apos;t light-skinned at all. Boy, was I wrong.<\/p>\n<p>And he used to put on such a show. He would get down on the floor, crawl like a wolf and sing in that voice: &quot;I&apos;m a tail dragger.&quot; He would do this boogie-woogie thing, around and around &#x2014; like the kids used to do with the hula hoops, where you had to go around and around at your waist, to keep the hoop going. That was the kind of shit he was doing. I&apos;d see that and think, &quot;Man, there goes the Wolf.&quot;<\/p>\n<p>He was so exciting to be on a show with. Wolf was a big man, but he could really move. It was like when the Chicago Bears had that player the Refrigerator. People think football players can&apos;t move when they&apos;re that big. And people expected the Wolf, because he was such a big guy, to just sit in a chair and belt it out. No, man, he had all that action. He had everything you wanted to see. He&apos;d crawl around, jump around. His fists were as big as a car tire. And he would ball that fist up. When I started getting calls to come and play on some cuts behind him, I&apos;d think, &quot;Oh, shit, I better play right.&quot; I&apos;d heard he was mean. I was told that. But, you know, I never had a cross word with the man the whole time, right up to when he passed away.<\/p>\n<p>The reason I got a chance to play on sessions with him &#x2014; on songs like &quot;Killing Floor,&quot; &quot;Built for Comfort&quot; and &quot;300 Pounds of Joy&quot; &#x2014; and a lot of musicians better than me didn&apos;t get those dates, was because they would come in thinking, &quot;This is my opportunity to blow the Wolf offstage.&quot; There was no way I could say that. This was my opportunity to learn something from the Wolf. But Wolf was not a demanding person. If you played something that made him smile, he would look back at you with that smile. When he did, to me, I was getting paid.<\/p>\n<p>I played with Muddy, too, and it was so great to play with both of them. I heard a rumor that Wolf and Muddy didn&apos;t get along &#x2014; I never saw that. Jimmy Rogers, who played in Muddy&apos;s band, used to laugh and joke about what Wolf had to say about Muddy and what Muddy would say back. But all of them talked bad about each other, calling everyone &quot;motherfucker.&quot; That was their thing. With musicians, &quot; motherfucker&quot; was the love word. And when Wolf said, &quot;Motherfucker, you can&apos;t play,&quot; what he was really saying was, &quot;I&apos;m gonna fire your ass up. If I tell you you can&apos;t play, then you&apos;re gonna bring it on.&quot; This is the way Wolf treated you. That would signify for you to show your shit.<\/p>\n<p>Everything you wanted was right there, touchable to me, in that voice &#x2014; even when Wolf wasn&apos;t singing. We used to have these Blue Mondays in Chicago that would start at seven o&apos;clock in the morning. That&apos;s when we&apos;d all get together after playing and just do a conversation, man. I would sit and listen to Wolf talk. It didn&apos;t have to be about music. He loved fishing, he loved sports. To me, it all sounded like music from heaven.<\/p>\n<p>People don&apos;t know him the way they should now. When Muddy died, they interviewed me on television, and they asked me, &quot;What should be done?&quot; I said most cities with famous musicians, like Chicago &#x2014; they end up naming a street or something after them. And they got the street that Muddy lived on most of his life named after him. But it never happened for Wolf. And the younger generation coming up now &#x2014; if you don&apos;t talk about the music or the artists, they don&apos;t know them. My children didn&apos;t know who I was until they were 21 and were able to come in the clubs and see me.<\/p>\n<p>We got to go back and do some digging. We have to let people know that Howlin&apos; Wolf &#x2014; and Muddy and Little Walter and all these cats &#x2014; made Chicago the world capital of the blues. Chess Records is a landmark. But who made Chess Records? What about those people we done forgot about, like Wolf?<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Owen Smith","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":457762,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135041-square.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135041-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135041-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135041-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135041-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135041-square.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div 20:51:00","modified":"2018-06-25 19:30:09","title":"The Allman Brothers Band","subtitle":null,"slug":"the-allman-brothers-band-88282","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Billy Gibbons&#xA0;<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p>In a way, their name says it all. It wasn&apos;t just about the fact that Duane and Gregg Allman had the same parents. The <a href=\"\/artist\/the-allman-brothers-band\">Allman Brothers Band<\/a> was a true brotherhood of players &#x2014; one that went beyond race and ego. It was a thing of beauty.<\/p>\n<p>The Allmans were without question the first great jam band, and they took the jam to heights that it had not previously reached. They played traditional blues mixed with their own unique brand of rock &amp; roll, and there was nothing but strength in that group.<\/p>\n<p>Duane Allman played what he wanted to hear. There have been bottleneck-guitar players forever, from the Twenties through the Sixties, but Duane began doing things no one had ever done before. He had a tone and a style that were uniquely his. He was just a stunning and singular musician who was gone way too soon.<\/p>\n<p>Then there was his kid brother, Gregg. His singing and keyboard playing had a dark richness, a soulfulness that added one more color to the Allmans&apos; rainbow. The Allman Brothers had respect for the roots of this music. They learned from the blues, and they continued to interpret the form in their own manner. They took something old and made something new.<\/p>\n<p>I was lucky enough to see the Allmans up close in the beginning. I first became aware of them when they were breaking out of Macon, Georgia. They had played Austin and made a tremendous noise down there. Word spread very quickly in those days. The next thing we knew we were on the road with these guys, opening up for them and Quicksilver Messenger Service, and witnessing music history.<\/p>\n<p>We would linger by the stage after our set and listen to Duane and Dickey Betts play guitar together. It was like they were weaving a beautiful piece of cloth. Dickey was remarkable in his own right. Yet in the beginning, no one in that band &#x2014; Duane, Dickey, Jaimoe Johanson or Butch Trucks &#x2014; outshined the others.<\/p>\n<p>There are a couple of moments on <em>At Fillmore East<\/em> that defy description &#x2014; where the Allmans take the music to places it had never been. That extended version of &quot;Whipping Post&quot; is the all-time end-all for me. The Allmans were the great Southern-rock band, but they were more than that. They defined the best of every music from the American South in that time. They were the best of all of us.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Illustration by Josie 15:10:00","modified":"2018-06-25 20:17:54","title":"Queen","subtitle":null,"slug":"queen-47204","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Gerard Way&#xA0;<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p>My dad was a mechanic. He worked on a lot of bottom-of-the-rung cars that didn&apos;t have cassette decks. But they had 8-tracks. Somebody left an 8-track tape of <a href=\"\/artist\/queen\">Queen<\/a>&apos;s <em>Greatest Hits<\/em> in a car &#x2014; the one where they&apos;re wearing leather jackets on the cover, and Freddie&apos;s got the mustache. I loved it immediately, and I came to emulate Freddie both as a child and as an adult.<\/p>\n<p>&quot;Bohemian Rhapsody&quot; is arguably the greatest song ever written. I&apos;m sure people told them it was too long or had too many movements. But then it came out and just took hold of the world. When you&apos;re in a band and you find something that breaks every rule, it gives you creative hope. And Queen were always trying something new; none of their hit songs were paint-by-numbers.<\/p>\n<p>When My Chemical Romance were making <em>The Black Parade<\/em>, we watched tons of documentary footage about <em>A Night at the Opera<\/em>, Queen&apos;s best album. We used Brian May amps and wrote songs with different movements. But we didn&apos;t try to make another &quot;Bohemian Rhapsody.&quot; Whenever someone tries to do that, they fail.<\/p>\n<p>I love the way Freddie performed. He would strike amazing poses; maybe he practiced them in front of a mirror, but he wasn&apos;t pretending to be somebody else. That was him telling the world, &quot;This is who I am.&quot; I remember when the surviving members of Queen were looking for a singer a few years ago, I was like, &quot;I would love to try it.&quot; Freddie&apos;s songs are just so much fun to sing, and he had such stamina. I would definitely have to quit smoking to be able to do what he did.<\/p>\n<p>Queen fell in and out of being cool, maybe because they were so sincere. Rock music is all about being phony sometimes. And they weren&apos;t. They were obviously so psyched to be doing what they were doing.<\/p>\n<p>They had a polarizing quality. I heard a story &#x2014; maybe apocryphal &#x2014; that Queen played a festival and got booed off the stage. Freddie vowed they would return as the biggest band in the world. And they did. When we played the Reading and Leeds festivals, we had to follow Slayer, and got bottles of piss thrown at us. I thought, &quot;If we ever come back here, we&apos;re gonna headline it.&quot; I&apos;ve always held on to the same dreams as Freddie.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Anita Kunz","url":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/music\/music-lists\/100-greatest-artists-147446\/","image_id":370605,"image":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135866-81bd39b294cc1cada3e1452af03d9b7a4da47ed2.jpg?w=306","sizes":{"pmc-gallery-s":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135866-81bd39b294cc1cada3e1452af03d9b7a4da47ed2.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-m":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135866-81bd39b294cc1cada3e1452af03d9b7a4da47ed2.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-l":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135866-81bd39b294cc1cada3e1452af03d9b7a4da47ed2.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135866-81bd39b294cc1cada3e1452af03d9b7a4da47ed2.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306},"pmc-gallery-xxl":{"src":"https:\/\/www.rollingstone.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/06\/rs-135866-81bd39b294cc1cada3e1452af03d9b7a4da47ed2.jpg?w=306","width":306,"height":306}},"fullWidth":306,"fullHeight":306,"mime_type":"image","ad":"","appleSongID":null,"enableAppleGA":false,"additionalDescription":null,"subtitleColor":null,"additionalSubtitle":null,"additionalSubtitleColor":null,"ads":{"html":"\t<div class=\"admz \" id=\"adm-in-list-x-47\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"adma boomerang \" data-device=\"Desktop\" data-width=\"728\">\n\t\t\t\t\n<div )\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t.setSubAdUnitPath(\"music\\\/list\\\/inbodyX\")\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t.addSize([[728,90],[3,3]])\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t.setLazyLoadMultiplier(2)\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t;\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t});\n\t\t<\/script>\n\t<\/div>\n<\/div>\n\t\t\t<\/div>\n\t\t\t\t<\/div>\n","data":[{"divId":"gpt-dsk-tab-list-inbodyX-uid48","displayType":"banner","targeting":[{"key":"pos","value":"mid"},{"key":"pos","value":"in-listX"},{"key":"pos","value":"btf"},{"key":"pos","value":"inbodyX"}],"lazyLoad":"yes","lazyLoadMultiplier":2,"zone":"music\/list\/inbodyX","sizes":[[728,90],[3,3]]}]}},{"ID":46935,"position":49,"positionDisplay":51,"date":"2011-04-26 15:09:00","modified":"2018-06-25 20:17:41","title":"Pink Floyd","subtitle":null,"slug":"pink-floyd-2-46935","caption":"","description":"<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pmc-not-a-paywall\"><p><em><span class=\"lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012\">By Wayne Coyne&#xA0;<\/span> <\/em><\/p>\n<p>When I was growing up in the 1970s, <a href=\"\/artist\/pink-floyd\">Pink Floyd<\/a> were ever-present. My brothers and my older sister and all their friends constantly played records in their rooms while they smoked pot. Especially <em>Dark Side of the Moon.<\/em> You heard that every day of your life, for at least three or four years around then.<\/p>\n<p>Turning 14 years old is already a heavy combination of things. For <em>Dark Side of the Moon<\/em> to be playing in the background during that time was perfect. As you looked deeper into their music, everything you find out leads to something interesting. Pink Floyd were always a group of great creative minds who did whatever the fuck they wanted and didn&apos;t worry about all the little rules.<\/p>\n<p>They had an amazing ability to change between records. You don&apos;t realize how powerful that is when you&apos;re just a listener. But being a person who&apos;s made 14 records, you see how big a deal it is. They have a phase one, a phase two, maybe even a phase three and four. A lot of groups &#x2014; if they&apos;re lucky &#x2014; just have a phase one.<\/p>\n<p>They started out with Syd Barrett writing these whimsical stories, these songs that were kind of surf-rock, kind of R&amp;B, but in his own fucked up way. Later you had Roger Waters evoking these big, universal landscapes of human crises. And Pink Floyd came to embrace this idea of &quot;We can play stadiums and we can fill them up with giant fucking pig balloons.&quot; Their music could just always hold that.<\/p>\n<p>Yet, despite all these different pieces moving around, there is a lot of very simple musicality going on. Compared to the prog-rock groups they get thrown in with &#x2014; King Crimson or Yes or Genesis &#x2014; their music is actually very simple. You can grasp the chord progressions and melodies the first time you hear them. I love all those other groups but with Pink Floyd I understand the emotion.<\/p>\n<p>Take a song like &quot;Fat Old Sun,&quot; from <em>Atom Heart Mother.<\/em> Living in Oklahoma, I sometimes can&apos;t relate when English bands sing about English things. When David Gilmour sings about the sun going down, there&apos;s something simple about it. It didn&apos;t seem like the sunset was happening in some king&apos;s country, in some other world. It seemed like he was singing about <em>me<\/em> walking in the sunsets in Oklahoma.<\/p>\n<\/div>","alt":"","image_credit":"Dale <meta class="swiftype" name="topics" data-type="string" content="Music Lists">
<meta class="swiftype" name="body" data-type="text" content="In 2004  50 years after Elvis Presley walked into Sun Studios and cut &quot;That's All Right&quot;  Rolling Stone celebrated rock &amp; roll's first half-century in grand style, assembling a panel of 55 top musicians, writers and industry executives (everyone from Keith Richards to ?uestlove of the Roots) and asking them to pick the most influential artists of the rock &amp; roll era. The resulting list of 100 artists, published in two issues of Rolling Stone in 2004 and 2005, and updated in 2011, is a broad survey of rock history, spanning Sixties heroes (the Beatles) and modern insurgents (Eminem), and touching on early pioneers (Chuck Berry) and the bluesmen who made it all possible (Howlin' Wolf).
The essays on these top 100 artists are by their peers: singers, producers and musicians. In these fan testimonials, indie rockers pay tribute to world-beating rappers (Vampire Weekend's Ezra Koenig on Jay-Z), young pop stars honor stylistic godmothers (Britney Spears on Madonna) and Billy Joel admits that Elton John &quot;kicks my ass on piano.&quot; Rock &amp; roll is now a music with a rich past. But at its best, it is still the sound of forward motion. As you read this book, remember: This is what we have to live up to.">

<aside class="read-next //  lrv-a-hidden@desktop-max lrv-u-flex lrv-u-align-items-center lrv-u-flex-1 lrv-u-font-family-body lrv-u-font-size-16 lrv-u-margin-l-125 lrv-u-overflow-hidden lrv-u-margin-r-1 lrv-u-font-family-body lrv-u-font-size-16 lrv-u-width-100p"><span class="c-span  lrv-a-font-body-xxs lrv-u-border-color-grey-light lrv-u-border-r-1 lrv-u-font-weight-bold lrv-u-padding-r-050 lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase lrv-u-whitespace-nowrap">

	
</span>
	
<h3 id="title-of-a-story" class="c-title  lrv-u-padding-l-050 u-max-width-500 lrv-u-line-height-small lrv-u-font-weight-normal">

	
	
		
							
	
</h3>

<div class="article-kicker larva // lrv-a-font-basic-s lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase lrv-u-display-inline-block lrv-u-padding-b-050 lrv-u-margin-b-075 prototype lrv-u-border-b-1">
						Music		 
	</div>

<h1 class="article-title larva // lrv-a-font-primary-xxl lrv-u-padding-b-050 u-font-size-30@mobile-max u-line-height-33@mobile-max u-width-90p@tablet u-width-85p@desktop u-width-80p@desktop-xl">100 Greatest Artists</h1>

<div class="article-excerpt larva // lrv-a-font-body-xl lrv-u-padding-b-075 u-letter-spacing-n006@mobile-max u-width-90p@tablet u-width-85p@desktop u-width-80p@desktop-xl">The Beatles, Eminem and more of the best of the best</div>
	</header><div class="a-article-grid__author lrv-u-margin-b-150">
		
<div class="author // lrv-u-font-size-16 lrv-u-font-family-body lrv-u-font-size-13@mobile-max">
			<div class="author-single-inner //  lrv-u-flex lrv-u-align-items-center ">
			<div class="author-content // lrv-u-flex@tablet lrv-u-width-100p lrv-u-justify-content-space-between ">
				<div class="author-content-inner // lrv-u-flex lrv-u-align-items-center lrv-a-glue-parent lrv-u-margin-b-025@mobile-max u-line-height-20 u-line-height-16@mobile-max ">
					<button class="author-button // lrv-u-display-contents lrv-u-flex lrv-u-align-items-center lrv-a-unstyle-button js-PopOver ">
						<p class="author-name // lrv-a-font-body-xxs lrv-u-margin-tb-00 lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase lrv-u-color-black lrv-u-color-black:hover u-letter-spacing-012 ">
							By 
<a class="c-link  lrv-u-color-black lrv-u-color-brand-primary:hover lrv-u-text-decoration-underline:hover" href="https://www.rollingstone.com/author/rolling-stone/">
	Rolling Stone</a>
						</p>

						
						<div class="author-detail-outer // lrv-a-hidden@desktop-max lrv-a-glue lrv-a-glue--l-0 lrv-a-glue--t-100p js-PopOver-target ">
							
<section class="author-details // lrv-u-flex lrv-u-flex-wrap-wrap lrv-u-margin-t-1 lrv-u-padding-lr-125 lrv-u-padding-t-125 lrv-u-padding-b-1 lrv-u-border-a-2 lrv-u-width-215 lrv-u-background-color-white lrv-a-glue-parent lrv-a-icon-after-arrow-top-left "><h3 id="c-title-657d72b989f2a7.90948814" class="c-title  lrv-u-margin-r-auto lrv-u-width-100 lrv-a-font-body-xxs lrv-u-font-weight-bold lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase">

	
			<a href="https://www.rollingstone.com/author/rolling-stone/" class="c-title__link lrv-u-color-black">
	
		
					Rolling Stone		
			</a>
	
</h3>

	<div class="author-details-icons // lrv-u-flex lrv-u-align-items-center lrv-u-margin-l-auto ">
					</div>

	
		
<nav class="o-nav  lrv-u-margin-t-075 lrv-u-border-t-1 lrv-u-padding-t-025 lrv-u-width-100p " data-dropdown=""><ul class="o-nav__list  lrv-u-border-t-1 lrv-u-border-b-1 lrv-u-padding-t-075 lrv-u-padding-l-1 lrv-a-font-body-xxxs lrv-u-list-style-type-disclosure-closed">
<li class="o-nav__list-item lrv-u-padding-b-075">
				
<a class="c-link  lrv-u-color-black" href="https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/karol-g-lil-baby-renee-rapp-songs-you-need-to-know-1234930143/">
	Karol G, Lil Baby, Rene Rapp and All the Songs You Need to Know This Week</a>
			</li>
					<li class="o-nav__list-item lrv-u-padding-b-075">
				
<a class="c-link  lrv-u-color-black" href="https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/culture-news/how-deep-patel-built-and-sold-a-mens-grooming-empire-for-8-figures-in-18-months-1234925409/">
	How Deep Patel Built and Sold a Mens Grooming Empire for 8 Figures in 18 Months</a>
			</li>
					<li class="o-nav__list-item lrv-u-padding-b-075">
				
<a class="c-link  lrv-u-color-black" href="https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/nicki-minaj-peso-pluma-tate-mcrae-songs-you-need-to-know-1234921684/">
	Nicki Minaj, Peso Pluma, Tate McRae and All the Songs You Need to Know This Week</a>
			</li>
			</ul></nav><div class="author-details-view-link //  lrv-u-flex lrv-u-margin-l-auto ">
				
<a class="c-link  lrv-u-font-size-10 lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase lrv-a-unstyle-link lrv-a-font-body-xs lrv-a-icon-after  a-icon-triangle-right a-icon-width-10" href="https://www.rollingstone.com/author/rolling-stone/">
	View all posts by Rolling Stone</a>
			</div>
		
	</section>
</div>
					</button>
				</div>

									<div class="author-timestamp-outer // lrv-u-margin-l-1@tablet lrv-u-flex-shrink-0">
						
<time class="c-timestamp  lrv-u-margin-l-auto lrv-u-color-black lrv-u-color-grey lrv-a-font-basic-xs lrv-a-font-basic-xxs@mobile-max lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase lrv-u-flex-shrink-0" datetime="2010-12-03 00:21:00.000000-0500">
	December 3, 2010	
</time>
</div>
							</div>
		</div>
	</div>
	</div>

	<div class="a-article-grid__featured-media">
		
<div class="featured-image">
	

<figure class="o-figure   lrv-u-max-width-100p" style=""><div class="c-lazy-image  ">
	
			<div class="lrv-a-crop-3x2" style="">
	
						<img class="c-lazy-image__img lrv-u-background-color-grey-lightest lrv-u-width-100p lrv-u-display-block lrv-u-height-auto" src="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/themes/vip/pmc-rollingstone-2022/assets/public/lazyload-fallback.gif" data-lazy-src="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rexfeatures_3553287j-ef334d61-d3df-4e8e-8b6c-76d0ebf54dd8.jpg?w=1581&amp;h=1054&amp;crop=1" alt="Best Artists of all time 100 Rolling Stone" data-lazy-srcset="" data-lazy-sizes="(max-width: 709px) 85vw, (max-width: 909px) 67vw, (max-width: 1362px) 62vw, 840px" height="" width="" decoding="async">
</div>
	
	</div>
	
			
			
<figcaption class="c-figcaption  lrv-u-font-size-12 lrv-u-padding-t-075"><span class="lrv-u-font-size-16 lrv-u-font-size-14@mobile-max lrv-u-font-family-body u-font-style-italic lrv-u-color-grey-dark u-line-height-20 u-letter-spacing-0 u-line-height-18@mobile-max lrv-u-margin-r-025">Rolling Stones in London circa 1960s.</span>
		
									<cite class="lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase lrv-u-color-grey lrv-u-font-size-10 u-line-height-13 lrv-u-font-family-basic lrv-u-font-weight-bold u-letter-spacing-003">REX</cite>
					
	</figcaption></figure>
</div>
	</div>

	<div class="a-content a-content--left-space lrv-a-floated-parent lrv-u-font-family-body lrv-u-line-height-normal lrv-u-font-size-18 js-Endmark u-padding-l-3125@tablet u-padding-l-625@desktop-xl">
		<!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! -->
				<div class="pmc-not-a-paywall">





























































































































































































































<p><span class="lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012">In 2004 </span>  50 years after Elvis Presley walked into Sun Studios and cut Thats All Right  <em>Rolling Stone</em> celebrated rock &amp; rolls first half-century in grand style, assembling a panel of 55 top musicians, writers and industry executives (everyone from Keith Richards to ?uestlove of the Roots) and asking them to pick the most influential artists of the rock &amp; roll era. The resulting list of 100 artists, published in two issues of <em>Rolling Stone</em> in 2004 and 2005, and updated in 2011, is a broad survey of rock history, spanning Sixties heroes (the Beatles) and modern insurgents (Eminem), and touching on early pioneers (Chuck Berry) and the bluesmen who made it all possible (Howlin Wolf).</p>
<p>The essays on these top 100 artists are by their peers: singers, producers and musicians. In these fan testimonials, indie rockers pay tribute to world-beating rappers (Vampire Weekends Ezra Koenig on Jay-Z), young pop stars honor stylistic godmothers (Britney Spears on Madonna) and Billy Joel admits that Elton John kicks my ass on piano. Rock &amp; roll is now a music with a rich past. But at its best, it is still the sound of forward motion. As you read this book, remember: This is what we have to live up to.</p>















</div> 
<div id="pmc-gallery-vertical">
	<div class="c-gallery-vertical-loader u-gallery-app-shell-loader">

		<div class="u-gallery-app-shell__figure u-gallery-app-shell u-gallery-react-placeholder-shimmer"></div>
<div class="u-gallery-app-shell__text u-gallery-app-shell u-gallery-react-placeholder-shimmer"></div>
<div class="u-gallery-app-shell__text-small u-gallery-app-shell u-gallery-react-placeholder-shimmer"></div>
<div class="u-gallery-app-shell__content u-gallery-app-shell__content-1 u-gallery-app-shell u-gallery-react-placeholder-shimmer"></div>
<div class="u-gallery-app-shell__content u-gallery-app-shell__content-2 u-gallery-app-shell u-gallery-react-placeholder-shimmer"></div>
<div class="u-gallery-app-shell__content u-gallery-app-shell__content-3 u-gallery-app-shell u-gallery-react-placeholder-shimmer"></div>
<div class="u-gallery-app-shell__content u-gallery-app-shell__content-4 u-gallery-app-shell u-gallery-react-placeholder-shimmer"></div>
		
<ul class="pmc-fallback-list-items lrv-a-unstyle-list lrv-u-margin-t-2">
<li class="pmc-fallback-list-item-wrap lrv-u-margin-b-2">
			<article class="pmc-fallback-list-item"><h2>Talking Heads</h2>

			<figure><img width="300" height="300" src="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/themes/vip/pmc-rollingstone-2022/assets/public/lazyload-fallback.gif" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt decoding="async" data-lazy-src="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135859-c4611e8b68f9e5ef934af7d2baffe7ee68bccb2c.jpg?w=300" data-lazy-srcset="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135859-c4611e8b68f9e5ef934af7d2baffe7ee68bccb2c.jpg 306w, https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135859-c4611e8b68f9e5ef934af7d2baffe7ee68bccb2c.jpg?resize=150,150 150w, https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135859-c4611e8b68f9e5ef934af7d2baffe7ee68bccb2c.jpg?resize=300,300 300w" data-lazy-sizes="(max-width: 300px) 85vw, 300px"><noscript><img width="300" height="300" src="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135859-c4611e8b68f9e5ef934af7d2baffe7ee68bccb2c.jpg?w=300" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="" decoding="async" srcset="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135859-c4611e8b68f9e5ef934af7d2baffe7ee68bccb2c.jpg 306w, https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135859-c4611e8b68f9e5ef934af7d2baffe7ee68bccb2c.jpg?resize=150,150 150w, https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135859-c4611e8b68f9e5ef934af7d2baffe7ee68bccb2c.jpg?resize=300,300 300w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 85vw, 300px"></noscript>							<figcaption>
					Image Credit: Olaf Hajek				</figcaption></figure><!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! --><div class="pmc-not-a-paywall">
<p><em><span class="lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012">By Dave Sitek</span> </em></p>
<p>When I was a kid, I was really into hardcore punk. Hardcore was very rigid. <a href="/artist/talking-heads">Talking Heads</a> was the first band I remember telling my punk friends about, saying, "Yo, check this out! This four-chord thing we're doing? We're missing out on something!"</p>
<p>The first song I really liked was "Once in a Lifetime." MTV had just started to sink its claws into people, and that song was like an anthem for coked-up adults trying to make sense of their world. <em>Remain in Light</em> was this combination of ambient music and strong lyrics and incredibly inventive percussion and bass parts. I was a kid, but I still thought, "I should have been involved in that record!" It's amazing.</p>
<p>They had so many things going on. If you listen to a Talking Heads bass line, you think the song's going one way, and then you listen to the drums and you think it's going a different way, and then you listen to David Byrne's lyrics and you're like, "This is a completely different song from what I thought it was going to be." And then the guitars come in, and then the ambience comes in  it's like several songs all blending into one. If Talking Heads were around a cool idea, they would make it their own. I feel like they saw Brian Eno, their producer, as another instrument.</p>
<p>The town that I grew up in was called Columbia, in Maryland. It was a planned community with man-made lakes. David Byrne's parents lived there for a while. It presented this facade that everything around us is solid and real and going to be here forever, even though we know we created it. Byrne's lyrics spoke to the artifice of the American landscape. The American Dream has a lot of back alleys, and he was showing those things, and I felt like, here's a guy trying to talk to me about something I had seen firsthand.</p>
<p>I think the artist's primary responsibility is to reflect what life was like in their time. Talking Heads did that. I'm all over the map emotionally and spiritually, like most people are, so different Talking Heads records speak to me at different times, but with <em>Remain in Light</em> and <em>Fear of Music</em>, the grit of modern living is there. What they're addressing still applies.</p>
<p>They weren't always complex, either  there's some stuff where it's just bare-bones essentials. "This Must Be the Place" is probably one of the most important songs in my entire life. I find the lyrics really calming. The song is simple, but when you look at all the elements and how they're put together and where the downbeat is, it's kind of  clever is not even really the word. Genius, maybe?</p>
</div></article>
</li>
			<li class="pmc-fallback-list-item-wrap lrv-u-margin-b-2">
			<article class="pmc-fallback-list-item"><h2>Carl Perkins</h2>

			<figure><img width="300" height="300" src="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/themes/vip/pmc-rollingstone-2022/assets/public/lazyload-fallback.gif" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt decoding="async" data-lazy-src="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135057-square.jpg?w=300" data-lazy-srcset="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135057-square.jpg 306w, https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135057-square.jpg?resize=150,150 150w, https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135057-square.jpg?resize=300,300 300w" data-lazy-sizes="(max-width: 300px) 85vw, 300px"><noscript><img width="300" height="300" src="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135057-square.jpg?w=300" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="" decoding="async" srcset="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135057-square.jpg 306w, https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135057-square.jpg?resize=150,150 150w, https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135057-square.jpg?resize=300,300 300w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 85vw, 300px"></noscript>							<figcaption>
					Image Credit: Illustration by Shawn Barber				</figcaption></figure><!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! --><div class="pmc-not-a-paywall">
<p><em>By Tom Petty</em></p>
<p><a href="/artist/carl-perkins">Carl Perkins</a>' songs will outlive us all. On tracks like "Blue Suede Shoes" and "Honey Don't!" he took that country-picking thing into the rock world. He was an amazing guitar player: If you want to play Fifties rock &amp; roll, you can either play like Chuck Berry, or you can play like Carl Perkins.</p>
<p>Considering how important he is to rock history, many people don't know about him. But the right people did. The Beatles covered five of Carl's songs on record. Carl was actually there in the studio when the Beatles cut some of them. Listen to the guitar break in "All My Loving": George Harrison told me that the Beatles would study the B sides of Carl's records to learn everything they could from him.</p>
<p>Carl was the real deal  a true rockabilly cat. He told me about picking cotton when he was a kid and learning the blues from an older black field hand he knew. Carl would go home from the fields, be practicing a Roy Acuff country type of thing on his guitar, and then he would start bending the notes. He told me his father would actually get mad, saying, "Play that thing right, boy, or don't play it at all." But it was organic with Carl. He took it to the honky-tonks  the real honky-tonks where people would be drinking out of a jug. It sounds like a clich now, that rock music was born out of cornfields and honky- tonks, but with Carl it was all true.</p>
<p>He didn't get the breaks he deserved; hard luck seemed to follow him around. He had a terrible car crash on the way to <em>The Ed Sullivan Show</em> when "Blue Suede Shoes" was breaking really big. Elvis ended up covering the song and took a lot of the glory there. Some people might not know that Carl played guitar with Johnny Cash for 10 years on the road. At a certain point in the Sixties, things got tough for Carl  he had a drinking problem, which he eventually overcame  and he went back into the lead-guitar business.</p>
<p>Carl himself was a very bright guy, and very funny. He once told me, "Tom, I like you so much  if I lived by you, I'd cut your grass." That warmth and wit came through in his music. He was not the kind of guy to blow his own horn; he was very humble. When we did a long stand at the Fillmore in the late Nineties, I talked Carl into sitting in with us. Backstage, Carl was very nervous about coming out with us. He said, "They may not know who I am." I told him, "Carl, they're going to know you and love you." When Carl hit the stage, he just ripped the room apart. Neil Young was there that night, and he was shaking his head. Carl was that good.</p>
</div></article>
</li>
			<li class="pmc-fallback-list-item-wrap lrv-u-margin-b-2">
			<article class="pmc-fallback-list-item"><h2>Curtis Mayfield</h2>

			<figure><img width="300" height="300" src="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/themes/vip/pmc-rollingstone-2022/assets/public/lazyload-fallback.gif" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt decoding="async" data-lazy-src="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135082-square.jpg?w=300" data-lazy-srcset="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135082-square.jpg 306w, https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135082-square.jpg?resize=150,150 150w, https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135082-square.jpg?resize=300,300 300w" data-lazy-sizes="(max-width: 300px) 85vw, 300px"><noscript><img width="300" height="300" src="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135082-square.jpg?w=300" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="" decoding="async" srcset="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135082-square.jpg 306w, https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135082-square.jpg?resize=150,150 150w, https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135082-square.jpg?resize=300,300 300w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 85vw, 300px"></noscript>							<figcaption>
					Image Credit: Illustration by Andrea Ventura				</figcaption></figure><!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! --><div class="pmc-not-a-paywall">
<p><em><span class="lrv-u-text-transform-uppercase u-letter-spacing-012">By Boz Scaggs</span> </em></p>
<p>If, in the late Fifties and early Sixties, you were drawn to that place on the AM radio dial where the rhythms, the grooves and the beautiful sounds of African-American soul were playing, you would have found <a href="/artist/curtis-mayfield">Curtis Mayfield</a>. Many of us first heard him as backing vocalist in the Impressions behind Jerry Butler, singing "For Your Precious Love." But he really came into focus in Butler's next big hit, "He Will Break Your Heart," which was written by Mayfield and features his strumming electric guitar to a saucy tango beat that you can hear echoing in Ben E. King's "Spanish Harlem."</p>
<p>After that he was front and center, singing the lead about a "Gypsy Woman" in an exotic brew of castanets and dark minor chords. At one point, after the lyric "She danced around and round to a guitar melody," he fired off an accent on his guitar that resonated for years for many of us who tried to emulate him  she cast her spell and he followed, with the rest of us close behind. You can clearly hear his influence in the monumental "Little Wing," by Jimi Hendrix.</p>
<p>But it was his voice that reached the higher ground. It burned with the abandon of the blues singer and an almost feminine longing, at once powerful and deeply personal. Women responded overwhelmingly to his profoundly respectful and sensitive approach. When he sang "The Wonder of You," the vulnerability and passion got in real close. They knew he knew.</p>
<p>At first, he made a gospel-like call to rise up, get on board, get ready. "I know you can make it," he exhorted to soul-stirring harmonizing. He later took the voice of activism, calling out diseases of urban America and challenging people to see what was going on, a plea Marvin Gaye would take up, too. The full range of his powers can be heard in the soundtrack to <em>Superfly.</em> It hits you in waves: driving rhythms with brass and strings countered by down-in-the-alley funk.</p>
<p>He was a dynamic performer right up until he was disabled in an accident onstage in New York in 1990. I only met him once, after a show in San Francisco. He was funny, gracious to all, had a beautiful smile and a genuine way about him  a gentle and humble man at heart.</p>
</div></article>
</li>
			<li class="pmc-fallback-list-item-wrap lrv-u-margin-b-2">
			<article class="pmc-fallback-list-item"><h2>R.E.M.</h2>

			<figure><img width="300" height="300" src="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/themes/vip/pmc-rollingstone-2022/assets/public/lazyload-fallback.gif" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt decoding="async" data-lazy-src="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135860-b7be8e2778c7b81e22ed148928b7b3043acfa0d8.jpg?w=300" data-lazy-srcset="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135860-b7be8e2778c7b81e22ed148928b7b3043acfa0d8.jpg 306w, https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135860-b7be8e2778c7b81e22ed148928b7b3043acfa0d8.jpg?resize=150,150 150w, https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135860-b7be8e2778c7b81e22ed148928b7b3043acfa0d8.jpg?resize=300,300 300w" data-lazy-sizes="(max-width: 300px) 85vw, 300px"><noscript><img width="300" height="300" src="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135860-b7be8e2778c7b81e22ed148928b7b3043acfa0d8.jpg?w=300" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="" decoding="async" srcset="https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135860-b7be8e2778c7b81e22ed148928b7b3043acfa0d8.jpg 306w, https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135860-b7be8e2778c7b81e22ed148928b7b3043acfa0d8.jpg?resize=150,150 150w, https://www.rollingstone.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/rs-135860-b7be8e2778c7b81e22ed148928b7b3043acfa0d8.jpg?resize=300,300 300w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 85vw, 300px"></noscript>							<figcaption>
					Image Credit: Illustration by Anita Kunz				</figcaption></figure><!-- do not apply CSS styles to this element! --><div class="pmc-not-a-paywall">
<p><em>By Colin Meloy</em></p>
<p>I first heard <a href="/artist/r-e-m">R.E.M.</a> in 1986, a song tacked on to the end of a demos collection of a Eugene, Oregon, band that my uncle, then in school at U of O, sent to me for Christmas. The song was called "Superman," a bit of meticulously crafted bubblegum that was so simple and honest and funny that my entire nascent library of cassettes (chiefly: Yaz, Scritti Politti and Depeche Mode) seemed to be rendered obsolete in the span of the track's three minutes. I was fully hooked. Little did I know: Becoming enamored with indie bands in Helena, Montana, in the late 1980s was kind of like developing a taste for beluga caviar in rationing-era postwar Britain.</p>
<p>By the time <em>Lifes Rich Pageant</em> was gracing the yellow Sony Sports boomboxes of the world, R.E.M. was totally a going concern. The following year brought <em>Document</em>, and that landed them a video on MTV, even. Still, in Helena, being an R.E.M. fan meant being part of a tiny community. A community that, as far as I could tell, consisted of exactly one person. Then <em>Green</em> came around, and suddenly this band was on a major label, playing arenas, and every human in America with two ears and access to radio was being demanded to "<em>Stand.</em>" I listened to <em>Chronic Town</em>  procured on a recent family vacation to Los Angeles  on my Walkman backstage during rehearsal for the school production of <em>Guys and Dolls</em>, rehearsing the conversation in my head:</p>
<p>"What are you listening to?" they'd ask.</p>
<p>"R.E.M.," I'd reply.</p>
<p>"Oh  they do that song 'Stand.'"</p>
<p>"Yeah," I'd reply casually, "I'm not really into that song  this is their first EP. It's, like, from 1982."</p>
<p>It was well-rehearsed, but it never actually happened. I had to suffer the philistines  stealing my band  silently. But still: To be an ardent R.E.M. fan, happy to venture beyond the pale of the radio singles, was a rare thing.
